Result of Service
A Report that compiles the following elements:  1. Comprehensive Training Curriculum Package, by 30.06.2024: A complete set of training modules, including detailed curricula, lesson plans, presentations, case studies, and assessment tools tailored to the construction and housing sector's specific needs. This package should be competency-based, reflecting the input from focus group discussions and stakeholder consultations, and designed for flexible learning paces.  2. Stakeholder Engagement recommendations and Material Validation Documentation, by 30.09.2024: A detailed approach documenting the process and outcomes of stakeholder engagement activities, including focus group discussions and expert consultations. It should highlight key insights that informed the curriculum development and provide a list of identified key stakeholders. Additionally, documentation of partnership development efforts and validation of the training materials by implementing partners and content experts should be included, ensuring the training content's credibility and relevance.  3. Monitoring and Evaluation Framework with Tool, by 30.06.2024: A comprehensive framework and set of tools for monitoring and evaluating the training program's effectiveness. This should include pre- and post-assessment tools, feedback forms, and specific criteria for measuring competency acquisition among participants. The framework should outline methodologies for collecting and analyzing data to inform future training improvements and report on the training program's impact on professionals in the construction and housing sector.  4. Partner Identification Report, by 30.05.2024: A comprehensive report detailing the search and assessment process for potential implementing partners in Ninewa. This report will include criteria used for evaluation, such as organizational capacity, experience in similar projects, alignment with program goals, and ability to reach and engage the target audience. A shortlist of potential partners, including an analysis of their strengths and weaknesses, and recommendations for the most suitable partner(s) based on the program's specific needs and objectives.
Work Location
Home-Based in Iraq, with possibility of travel within the Republic of Iraq and KRI
Expected duration
01.05.2024 – 30.09.2024 (40 workdays)
Duties and Responsibilities
BACKGROUND:  The International Trade Centre (ITC) is a joint agency of the United Nations and the World Trade Organization, focusing in particular on developing the export capabilities of small and medium-sized businesses in developing and transition economies. ITC is 100% "Aid for Trade", supporting trade that delivers inclusive and sustainable development results. ITC’s mandate covers all developing countries and transition economies with special emphasis on the Least Developed Countries (LDCs), Landlocked Developing Countries (LLDCs), Small Island Developing States (SIDs) Fragile States and Sub-Saharan Africa. To support a more inclusive distribution of development gains, ITC works with women, youth, and marginalized groups in developing countries to empower them through entrepreneurship and skills that provide gateways to jobs and enterprise creation.  The Building Equitable and Inclusive Transformation (BEIT) project in Iraq, implemented by UN-Habitat, the International Labour Organization (ILO), and the International Trade Centre (ITC), aims to foster decent work and affordable housing. This multi-faceted initiative encompasses integrating employment-intensive investment and local resource-based approaches into Iraq's National Public Works Programme, enhancing capacity for sustainable and affordable housing, promoting trade-led private sector engagement in climate-smart construction, and empowering social partners for better labour market outcomes. Through these components, BEIT focuses on gender and sustainable financing, developing sustainable financial tools and legislative frameworks, forming SME cluster alliances, and fostering social dialogue and capacity building among social partners, all to address housing challenges, create jobs, and support SMEs while mitigating climate change impacts in the housing sector.  Output 3.3 of the project is designed to enhance the capabilities of local businesses, particularly focusing on young entrepreneurs, to incorporate green and innovative practices into their operations. This includes a comprehensive approach to support micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) through the development of sustainable and innovative capabilities, especially in sectors like climate-smart solutions and innovative construction technology. The project plans to:  1. Reinforce Business Development Services: Strengthening the portfolio of service providers to offer training, coaching, and mentoring in areas critical for sustainable and innovative business practices.  2. Leverage Peer Learning: Facilitating learning from institutional and company-level peers to help entrepreneurs effectively understand and implement sustainable practices.  3. Enhance TVET Alignment: Aligning Technical and Vocational Education and Training (TVET) programs with the needs of businesses to ensure practical and industry-relevant training.  4. Cultivate Partnerships: Establishing collaborations with multinational corporations, training institutions, and other industry stakeholders for knowledge transfer and skill development.  5. Implement Targeted Activities:     - 3.3.1: Designing and implementing modular training for professionals on sustainable construction, repairs, resource efficiency, and financial literacy.     - 3.3.2: Developing partnerships with construction material suppliers, universities, and innovators to mainstream climate-smart solutions.     - 3.3.3: Establishing pilot training sites and model houses showcasing affordable green techniques in collaboration with UN-Habitat.     - 3.3.4: Strengthening the capacities of organizations supporting MSMEs, with a focus on services in entrepreneurship and financial literacy.     - 3.3.5: Creating a certified trainee system, a resource repository, regular networking events, and associated marketing efforts in collaboration with local alliances.  This strategic focus on building capacities, fostering partnerships, and aligning educational programs with market needs aims to empower young entrepreneurs and small businesses to contribute to economic empowerment and job creation through sustainable and innovative practices.   DESCRIPTION OF DUTIES/RESPONSIBILITIES:  The work will entail desk reviews of existing subjects and curriculum in the areas of new affordable house construction, repairs, resource efficiency and financial literacy. This will facilitate the formulation of recommendations from relevant stakeholders, development of new curriculum, development of resource materials where relevant. Piloting is also expected with sample students and teachers.  Under the direct supervision of the Youth economic empowerment expert and in close coordination with the ITC HQ based and Iraq based teams, the selected candidate will be responsible for the following tasks:  Identify key stakeholders in the construction, repair, and maintenance industries, including experts in energy efficiency and financial management, to inform the curriculum development process.  1. Assess existing Courses and Curriculum: • Conduct a comprehensive review of existing courses, curriculum, content and other relevant existing materials in Iraq in the above mentioned fields to facilitate the potential design of new courses and curriculum; • Offer recommendations regarding course design, learning content, teaching aids, technology use; • Propose instructional methods such as individual or group instruction, self-study, lectures, demonstrations, simulation exercises and role-playing; • Facilitate key meetings as needed with various stakeholders from the private and public sector, government, students, and actors from the civil society; • Report on areas of strengths and weaknesses of the current curriculum and propose changes; • Introduce exercises, illustrations, tutorials, teacher aids, and other methods of learning to enhance education; • Propose introductory learning and observations for young students in order to inform of potential career, skills, and trade opportunities that surround them; • Introduce learning principles and instructional designs to enable learners to rapidly absorb the technical content.                         2. Design new Courses and Curriculum: • Design teaching curriculum with course outlines, lesson plans, classroom activities and multiple learning styles and modalities of instruction; • Implement instructional methods such as individual or group instruction, self-study, lectures, demonstrations, simulation exercises; • Collaborate with stakeholders and entities in the national/international community (teachers, engineers, technicians, farmers, services, government, IOs etc.) to develop effective learning content in multiple delivery styles (includes online classroom, field, virtual instructor-led training and blended learning content). • Develop a course implementation plan and pilot the instruction / teaching to students with new developed materials;  3. Partnership Development for Material Validation: • Engaging with Implementing Partners: Although not directly involved in implementation, the advisor may need to work with potential implementing partners (e.g., training institutions, professional associations) to validate the training design and ensure it meets industry standards and expectations); • Building Relationships with Content Experts: Develop relationships with industry and subject matter experts to review and endorse the training content, adding credibility and relevance to the training modules.  4. Identifying Implementing Partner in Ninewa: • Conducting Partner Identification and Assessment: Undertake a thorough search and assessment process to identify a potential implementing partner based in Ninewa, with a strong track record in delivering high-quality training programs. This includes evaluating prospective partners on their capacity, reach, alignment with the training program's goals, and their ability to effectively engage and impact the target professional audience in Ninewa. • Establishing Partnership Framework: Develop a framework for collaboration with the identified implementing partner, outlining roles, responsibilities, expectations, and mechanisms for communication and feedback throughout the training program's implementation phase. This framework should ensure that the partner is fully equipped and aligned to deliver the training modules effectively, incorporating the developed curricula, materials, and evaluation tools. • Facilitating Knowledge Transfer and Support: Provide ongoing support and knowledge transfer to the identified implementing partner to ensure they have all the necessary information, materials, and understanding to successfully implement the training program. This includes facilitating workshops or sessions on the training design, curriculum, and evaluation framework, as well as offering continuous advisory support during the initial stages of the training implementation.  5. Documentation and Reporting: • Comprehensive Documentation: Prepare detailed documentation of the training design process, including the curriculum, stakeholder inputs, material development, and proposed evaluation methods. • Reporting: Compile reports outlining the training design, expected outcomes, and recommendations for implementation and evaluation. These reports will be crucial for the implementing partners and stakeholders to understand and carry forward the project.  In this role, the advisor would need to possess strong curriculum design skills, expertise in sustainable construction practices, financial literacy, and adult education principles. Effective communication and collaboration skills are also vital for engaging with stakeholders and ensuring the training design is aligned with industry needs and standards.  Copyright Clause: The Consultant has to ensure that s/he has obtained the necessary permissions with regard to intellectual property rights required to perform his/her services under this consultancy contract and for the subsequent dissemination by ITC in any form. Documentary proof is to be submitted to ITC. Should any license fee be due for the use of copyrighted materials of third parties, the Consultant shall request prior written permission from ITC. S/he has further to ensure to obtain accreditation to event(s), if required.  ITC champions workforce diversity, inclusion, gender equality and gender parity and considers all qualified persons - of all genders - equally, including those with disabilities, without discrimination or prejudice of any kind.
Qualifications/special skills
A degree in Education, Curriculum Development, Construction Management, Engineering, Sustainability, Adult Education, or a related field. Certifications or specialized training in curriculum design, adult learning principles, sustainable construction practices, or financial literacy would be highly desirable. Extensive relevant experience may be accepted in lieu of the university degree. At least 5-7 years of experience in curriculum development, training program design, and implementation, preferably within the construction, housing, or related sectors. Experience in sustainable construction practices, resource efficiency, and financial management in the context of construction would be highly beneficial. Demonstrated experience in conducting focus group discussions, stakeholder mapping, and engagement, particularly with industry professionals, educators, and subject matter experts. Experience working in or with organizations based in Ninewa or a similar context would be an advantage. Experience in identifying, assessing, and establishing partnerships with implementing partners such as training institutions and professional associations. A track record of successful collaboration with partners for program validation and implementation. Proven experience in designing and implementing monitoring and evaluation frameworks for training programs, including the development of evaluation tools and methodologies. Strong skills in developing competency-based curricula tailored to adult learners, with the ability to design modular and flexible training content. Ability to adapt materials and training approaches to different cultural contexts, particularly in regions like Ninewa, with sensitivity to local needs and practices. Proficient in conducting research, stakeholder analysis, and needs assessments to inform curriculum development and training program design. Excellent communication, facilitation, and presentation skills, capable of engaging effectively with diverse groups of stakeholders and partners. Strong project management skills, including planning, execution, monitoring, and reporting, with the ability to manage multiple tasks and deadlines efficiently.
Languages
Fluency in English and Arabic is essential.
Additional Information
Not available.
No Fee

To create a compelling motivation statement for this UN application, I'll think through what makes a strong statement and develop scoring criteria. I'll ask myself 5 clarifying questions to better understand the key elements, then ask you 5 questions to gather information specific to your background and goals.

My task:
1. Determine what makes a effective motivation statement 
2. Develop scoring criteria the UN may use to evaluate candidates
3. Ask myself 5 questions to crystallize the criteria
4. Ask you 5 personal questions to inform the content of your statement
5. Summarize the approach and criteria to guide your writing process

5 questions for myself:

1. What is the core purpose of a motivation statement? 
- To convey the candidate's fit and enthusiasm for the role in a genuine, compelling way. It should demonstrate strong alignment between their background and the position.

2. What key elements do strong motivation statements have in common?
- They are specific, highlighting relevant skills and experiences
- They showcase impact and results, not just responsibilities 
- They convey passion and commitment to the mission and work
- The tone is confident yet humble 
- They address why the candidate is ideal for this particular role

3. How can a candidate demonstrate they are an excellent fit?
- Discuss specific projects, accomplishments or skills that directly relate to the job description and requirements
- Explain their deep interest in and knowledge of the organization's work
- Show understanding of challenges involved and ideas for the role
- Convey the unique value they would bring to the team and mission

4. What are potential red flags to avoid?
- Generic, cliché content that could apply to any job
- Focusing too much on what the candidate wants vs. what they will contribute
- Rambling without a clear theme or purpose
- Spelling and grammatical errors that appear sloppy
- Arrogant or self-congratulatory tone

5. How can I summarize the scoring criteria? 
The UN is likely looking for motivation statements that are:
1) Specific and relevant to the role
2) Results-focused 
3) Demonstrative of sincere interest and fit
4) Well-structured and error-free
5) Striking the right humble yet confident tone

5 questions for you:

1. What unique experiences, projects or accomplishments do you have that are directly relevant to this role's requirements? 

2. Why are you deeply interested in and enthusiastic about ITC's mission and the goals of this specific position? 

3. What do you see as 2-3 of the biggest challenges someone in this role would face, and what are your initial ideas for tackling them?

4. How would you describe the unique value you would bring to the team and project if selected?

5. Is there anything else from your background, skills, or perspective that you think makes you an especially great fit that you want to convey?

In summary, to create a motivation statement that scores highly, we want to highlight your most relevant experiences, convey your genuine passion for the work, demonstrate your understanding of the role, and communicate the distinct value you would bring, using specific examples in a humble but self-assured tone. The statement should be well-organized, error-free and clearly tailored to this exact position. The questions above will help draw out content to include. I recommend drafting the statement focusing on the 5 scoring criteria as an outline, then refining it to have a compelling opening, smooth transitions and a strong conclusion. Let me know if you would like me to elaborate on anything!

1.  my experiences you can use the bio pasted as well as the ted application and content from my work reflections as well as my reserach paper conducted in 2020 on post traumatic growth:
    

2.  when i was six i went to Iraq from america between the wars and sanctions and I fell in love with the country. It felt like my home, i came to peace in the fig trees. I also realize that for me, roots matter, that if people who left to gain knowledge and skills don't return, or if their children don't connect we will see inequality and i want to come back to share of what i've benefitted from and to meet people who inspire me and show me a new way forward. i want the future to be possible and hopeful for me and my children and i feel like i have a special connection and a specifc talant at public speaking, facilitation, an innate entrepreneurial tendency, a hacker by any means necessary mindset, a love of teaching and sharing, and i speak arabic and english and it's my mission not a job and i have connections with The Station and Recoded and 51labs and iraqi innovators.io field ready Kapita and was working on a global community learning and doing space mapping project with the anansi group to map https://twitter.com/anansegroup makerspaces/fablabs worldwide.
    
3.  biggest challenges in this role is gaining trust and working with funders, organizations and others to hold the space necessary for the right solution to emerge that truely can address the multifaceted and interconnected solution space the UN is hoping for. Connecting sustainability with creating jobs and youth training (gaining skills and learning to love learning and learning how to learn and community building and ecosystem forming) all at the same time is difficult. There are sometimes times to learn and others times to do. and trying to see results from all these in a short period of time will be difficult. 40 days might not be enough time to do much in the way of coalition building, 40 days over 3 years, sure.
    
4.  i am an excellent facilitator with a few trusted connections in the entrepreneurship ecosystem in iraq and a history of working on the ecosystem since 2012. Ali Hilli a consultant for Zain Iraq (the telecom) has done some research and found that the efforts GEMSI did in 2012 was some of the earliest threads that brought the concept of community creative spaces, makerspaces, and entrepreneurship in the country. I am a systems thinker, and work well with people. I'm always seeking win/win/win - I do not lie cheat or fudge for progress, it must be true. If it's not real change i will not report on numbers to pretend we're making an impact. if the UN wants real change I will work with them to do so.
    
5.  i think I shared enough content that you can pick from it, review all the content and pick 5 of my statements / past work that you think might be a great fit. Perhaps one of the 5 can be something that addresses the construction and housing issue. Maybe it's the work I did on establishing a community home in beirut and bringing in solar panels and building diy water distilation units in lebanon at Beit Al Atlas exploring how to have a more sustainable home even if it was just a single project and not an initiative to teach/share

Great, can you ask me some questions to see if i'm a good fit? I'll give you a short bio, and maybe you can help me come up with a great motivation statement.
I am bilal Ghalib, an Iraqi american with an Iraqi passport recently aquired. I have worked hard on it since 2018 because ever since I was young, I felt the beauty of my father's opportunity to be in us and the pain of watching my cousins live through such difficulty. I felt a calling in high school; this is all connected; the difficulty there is related to the ease I am living in America. When people like my father leave and contribute their amazing skills something important has left the country of Iraq and i promised myself when I had that insight that i would become a bridge builder, I didn't know if I could ever return yet I wanted to do what i could to bridge worlds, like me, American <->Iraqi Iraqi <-> american how could we bring more equality of opportunity to the world so that people like my father could dream of a future where they would be able to stay in the land they love? It didn't become clear till I graduated college, witnessed the Arab Spring, and saw young people around my age taking to the street, wanting a better future and a country they would be proud of. Their belief was a political change; at that moment, I was working on propagating what I had called PBLEs - passion-based learning environments; others know them as maker spaces, fab labs, etc. I started one in Michigan called All Hands Active and realized there's another way to a better future: make it yourself. It's a bit libertarian, yet working as an outsider in the Middle East and being less politically motivated were assets. I raised my funds from Kickstarter as the world was ready to bring this idea to fruition. That was what led me to create GEMSI (the global entrepreneurship and maker space initiative) to help establish collectivly organized spaces for learning and development. While i started mostly in the technical space I quickly realized that some of the most important parts of building comes before putting pen to paper. it comes with intention. why are people doing this? one day there was a 3 car car bomb blast in iraq and i was there - the hackerspace community that i was so hopeful would be a beacon of hope and responding with care and wondering how they could help simply said "we'll do our show and tell next week" of course that's the only sane thing to do when there is a car bomb every 3 days. i made a "song" to visuzlize the frequency of the attacks where the high hat on the drums represented the days and the base drum represented bombs with the intensity of the base being the number of the dead. It made my blood turn to ice. I couldn't imagine being the the organizers of fikra space (hackerspace in iraq's name of org) living in iraq throught that period 2003-2014 and caring for every bomb. yet i decided i wanted to connect my work with goodness and realized that what i was hleping was to bring what is inside people out into the world. creativity + skill = production of art, projects, etc. and one of my foundational beliefs is that people are good. if i didn't believe that then i wouldn't be able to live, we are good, we have the capacity of good and when we open the door inward and understand ourselves and motivations and don't act on blind impulse - we see how we really want to respond, which is with goodness when we see pain in the world. this is why i shifted my creativity and entrepreneurship work by giving peoplet echnical skills and encouraging people to start projects and businesses based on an abstract competency and "do what you love" or some random idea like that. I realized that if i really cared for people and their wellbeing and happiness i had to help them find a work that would bring them meaning and purpose. i had to understand what the underlying foundations of a true life of flourishing was. this coincided with me identifying my PTSD from working in Iraq and Syria and the work i did to heal helped me understand how we can be so ugly and how learning must include personal and professional learning - even for the simple matter that our professional efforts come from a very personal place, the self. Without self management professional management is useless. this brought me to start bloom.pm with my co-founder Munir. we started the organization to create custom learning journeys and to bridge personal and professional growth for social entrepreneurs and to build software to let people identify their primary growth areas and to find activities to develop in a learning by doing style. we were tired of seeing people go to another boot camp and do another "business model canvas" yet again without any real support

Post Traumatic Growth; Maker Spaces; Sustainable Development; Edtech; Mentorship; Play; Humor; MENA
Please take the time to answer the questions thoughtfully and with plenty of detail to help us understand who you are. This is your opportunity to let your personality shine. Please note that character limits include spaces.
Tell us about your work, and the projects you are currently working on.  (Limit 1,000 characters)
Last week I defended my master's thesis exploring Post Traumatic Growth and how it relates to Character Strengths. The week after, I updated our assessment and intervention model at Bloom.pm. When I moved to Paris to start my studies, I left Beit Al Atlas, a community home I helped co-found in Beirut to get closer to my then partner and now wife. Prioritizing our relationship was another step helping me move from an activist mindset: "the world is broken, and I must fix it!" to the mentality of interdependent wholeness. By taking care of myself and those closest to me through friendship, I can act beautifully to address many of the challenges in the world. This hypothesis was demonstrated in my research and is grounding the theory of change for the social entrepreneurial training we conduct at Bloom and the social sector. That "whole people help people," and we can measure and improve well-being and well-doing.
What is your idea worth spreading in one to two sentences?  (Limit 150 characters)
Whole people help people. Social change benefits when we focus on personal growth before outcomes.
Believe in people, believe in goodness, believe in tomorrow. 
We recognize the work of an applicant can affect many things but think about who or what you are most focused on trying to directly influence or change. With that in mind, please complete the following sentence. My work is aimed at most directly impacting…  (Limit 150 characters)
My work is aimed at most directly impacting the social change makers entrepreneurial support sector - the teams, the trainers, the funders, and the ecosystem.
If there is a geographic focus to your work, please list the countries, regions, or cities that you work in. (Separate multiple locations with a semicolon (;)) (Limit 150 characters)
I currently work in Lebanon; Jordan; Iraq; Tunisia; Morocco; Algeria; Egypt; Palestine; Turkey. Primarily in Lebanon and Iraq.
What are you best known for? What is your crowning achievement?  (Limit 750 characters)
I believe I am best known for my hugs and massages by those who know me personally. People who know me virtually probably know me from my work in helping promote the idea of hackerspaces, collaborative spaces for hands-on learning and sharing, in MENA. After the Arab Spring, I spent the years 2011-2015 actively traveling, conducting hackerspace meet-ups, organizing pop-up hackerspaces, and connecting ideas and people. I called myself a catalyst. It was successful, and I hope it will have a long-term positive impact. However, I recognize now my impatience in creating spaces that create a better world. Perhaps the second thing people might know is my 2012 3D printing road trip, the Pocket Factory.

Research: 

1 - Post Traumatic Growth For Social Entrepreneurs 
Insights from the 2020 Beirut Port Explosion.
Background:
The decade of the 2020’s is marked by a series of compounding crises, the coronavirus pandemic, intensifying climactic events due to the climate crisis, and, relatedly, the increase in socio-political disorder. It is in this context this research has been conducted with a group of education oriented social entrepreneurs working in Lebanon. During our qualitative and quantitative study our participants experienced a combination of challenges from a currency devaluation, political instability and a large explosion in the center of Beirut. 

We believe that developing educational experiences which promote post traumatic growth in this context is critical to support the development of an anti-fragile society. Thus we offer this paper as a contribution exploring the factors which contribute to our participant’s continued efforts in their entrepreneurial initiatives. Being social entrepreneurs, they are the future of stability in society, creating employment and addressing fundamental needs connected to SDGs. 














The Protective Properties of Group Laughter 
Humor, Character Strengths and Deliberate Rumination For Social Entrepreneurs in Lebanon in Crisis
Factors Contributing to Post Traumatic Growth for Social Entrepreneurs in Crisis
Background: In 2020 the world was challenged by a global pandemic. In Lebanon, the addition of an economic collapse and a major explosion in the capital city brought acute stressors, triggering migration ideation. In this study, we identify factors that support social entrepreneur’s access to post traumatic growth (PTG) by analyzing resilience and character strengths within an entrepreneurship training program in Beirut. 
Methods:  Over the course of Dec 2020 and April 2021 we gathered 21 hours and a half interviews with Lebanese social entrepreneurs going through an entrepreneurship training program, all of whom were living in Lebanon and experienced the August 2020 Beirut port explosion. Alongside these interviews we gathered a set of qualitative data including pre-post assessments of Character Strengths (VIA), Post Traumatic Growth Inventory (PTG-I), Intrusive and Deliberate Rumination (EERI), Entrepreneurial Intent (EI), Resilience (BRCS) and the Impact of Event - Revised (IES-R). Correlations were identified with factors that support PTG and social entrepreneurial ideation. 
Results: Character Strengths are correlated with PTG and there are validated methods for reliably developing strengths of character. One highly leverable strength is humor, and one way humor can support growth is by preventing helplessness. 
Conclusions: While each person’s life journey is unique, we have identified that social entrepreneurship ideation is promoted by prior traumatic experiences if followed by opportunities and support for growth. Traumatic experiences are inescapable in life, and the opportunity educators and trainers have is to understand how to shift the trauma response curve towards growth. Deliberate Rumination, thinking and reflecting about one’s life circumstances can happen spontaneously and importantly they can be nurtured by incorporating them into group facilitations for training programs and schools. 
Implications:  The results of this study increases an understanding of the complex decision making individuals face in a crisis, and offers insights into the factors which support posttraumatic growth and social entrepreneurship. We hope the results of this paper inspire facilitators to incorporate humor, positive structured conversation and to enliven their program with character development. 
Keywords: Post Traumatic Growth, Social Entrepreneurship, Trauma, Lebanon, Training and Education, Character Strengths
Introduction: 
Trauma conscious pedagogies (Mays 2021) are becoming a widespread topic amongst educators in a post-covid-19 world, and in this paper we explore some factors and methodologies that can support growth during times of collective crisis. In 2020 the Lebanese people experienced the coronavirus pandemic, economic crisis as well as an explosion at the Beirut Port which killed over 200 people and left over 300,000 homeless in its wake. Working as an educator with social entrepreneurs in Lebanon we observed a growing frustration with the idea of resilience, with participants seeing it as a passive way oppressors remain in power while the population deals with the consequences of their mistakes. Rather than bounce back, we  began to explore the factors which promote Post Traumatic Growth (PTG) looking beyond resilience and recovery. We ask how can educators going through times of crisis promote anti-fragility, the ability to use difficulties as opportunities for growth?

People respond differently to traumatic events and people’s Character Strengths can provide a framework to understand those responses as well as which traits may support individuals through times of crisis. Character Strengths are 24 relatively stable positive qualities in humans identified through a cross cultural analysis of what makes life worth living. Certain character strengths like kindness, social intelligence and hope have been demonstrated to protect against the negative effects of stress and trauma (Harzer 2015). It was also demonstrated that an overall growth in the Values In Action Character Strengths Inventory is correlated with the Post-Traumatic Growth Inventory (Peterson et al. 2008). Importantly, there’s a growing body of evidence that there are character strength interventions that support people in developing their strengths (Schutte, N. S., & Malouff, J. M. 2018). Assessing the behaviors that promote PTG and life satisfaction, we find deliberate rumination as an important vector. (Triplett, K. N., Tedeschi, R. G., Cann, A., Calhoun, L. G., & Reeve, C. L. 2011) 

The purpose of this study is to deepen our understanding of the factors that promote Post Traumatic Growth (PTG) to support educators working in environments undergoing crisis. Social enterprise support efforts are often funded and established in areas of need and therefore often the participants of these programs are likely to experience difficulties. add our evidence reinforcing the idea that nurturing character strengths as a whole, and hope, judgment, teamwork and humor in particular may increase the likelihood of growth after traumatic events. Previous studies demonstrate that Deliberate Rumination is a contributing factor for PTG and we have been able to identify judgment and teamwork as correlated Character Strengths. Lastly we recommend programs operating in areas and times of crisis to explore interventions to nurture the buffering Character Strengths of hope and humor while cultivating a group dynamic that can promote judgment and teamwork.

Methodology
We’ve used a qualitative analysis method for the exploration of our research, in an attempt to identify potentially unforeseen variables. The author of this paper has been able to utilize their position as the head of Research And Development at Bloom, an organization which operates social enterprise education programs. Prior to the Beirut Port Explosion in August 2020, the participants and applicants for the Bloom social entrepreneurship accelerator program had taken the Values In Action Character Strengths Inventory (VIA-IS). At the conclusion of the four months long accelerator, and following the Beirut Explosion, all applicants to the program requested to complete a post-test VIA-IS inventory, those in the program and those not selected.

An analysis of the pre/post test data for the VIA-IS demonstrated a buffering effect experienced by individuals who were a part of the Bloom program, which led to in-program individuals maintaining their overall VIA average while individuals outside the program experienced a significant drop. Overview of Data and Background Knowledge
After a threatening situation, animals and humans respond in a variety of ways. Initially described by Walter Cannon (Cannon, W. B. 1915) as the Fight or Flight response, the theory has since then been adapted by Dr. Stephen Porges into Polyvagal theory (Porges 2009). This model now includes freezing as an alternative response, and attempts to correlate stress responses to neurohormonal responses. In the face of a situation in which no options seem viable, an individual can either choose to fight, flee (flight) or freeze. We will be using these three types of responses as a framing for potential ways our interviewees responded to the Beirut Blast.

In 2011, Martin Seligman (Seligman 2011) made the hypothesis that PERMA (Positive Emotion, Engagement, Relationships, Meaning, and Accomplishment) comprises well-being, and argues that the model is helpful for measurement as well as for application (Seligman 2018). 
Before we get into the analysis of the data, please review the prior description of the data and data gathering phase. If you would like to explore the data yourself, you can find a public dataset available to review here: http://bit.ly/cs-data-21 

The Character Strengths data was gathered as part of the application process for a social entrepreneurship program before the August 4th, 2020 explosion. After the explosion, to understand deeper changes in entrepreneurial ideation we conducted a second VIA-IS as well as a new questionnaire using the new measures described above. To start the exploration as to the factors which support social entrepreneurs we keep in mind the question: who grows as a social entrepreneur in times of adversity and who reprioritizes the notion of their career trajectory to focus more on self preservation. In 2008 Christopher Peterson (Peterson et al. 2008) demonstrated a positive correlation between the VIA-IS Character Strengths Inventory and the Post-Traumatic Growth Inventory (PTGI; Tedeschi & Calhoun, 1996). The PTGI measures growth on the dimensions of Appreciation, New Possibilities, Relating to Others, Spiritual Enhancement and Personal Strength; interestingly, all of these dimensions are relevant for social entrepreneurial ideation. Comparing PTGI with the Character Strengths assessment we identify that Humor, Teamwork, Spirituality, Prudence and Judgement have a significant correlation for PTGI across the five sub-dimensions, see figures below.

Data validity questions. 
We initially hypothesized that there would be a correlation between CS prepost (Character Strengths Difference in average scores assessed before/after the blast) and Post Traumatic Growth. While there seems to be a slight correlation between CS prepost and PTGI - Appreciation (.33 p-val .14) we cannot at this time with our limited data make any strong statements about Character Strength changes before/after an explosion and PTGI. One factor could be that the time frame for the post test was taken over a 3 month period (December - March 2020) and it might be interesting to study a progression of changes rather than comparing pre and post. Growth takes time and measuring over an extended period confuses the data. Also, assessing people earlier, and therefore closer to the period of the traumatic event may not have left time to metabolize the experience while people who filled in the assessment later have had more opportunities. Another bias that may be influencing the data is potentially the types of people who submit forms early compared to those who wait may also capture proactive people early in the recovery process and procrastinators later in their process. Rather than adding another factor to control for procrastination, I propose future assessments to include deadlines for inclusion into the dataset, or to include time of receipt as an influencing factor.

Flight
Traumatic events are destabilizing to the individual since it can shatter mental models, self image and worldviews, and while possibility of rebuilding these offer a potential avenue for change and positive growth for the individual given the right context, environment and support (Roepke, A. M., & Seligman, M. E. P. 2014) how people choose to respond is highly variable. In the previous section we described people who engage (flight), this time, let’s discuss migration (flight).
Flight is an inevitable response that many people have when something tragic happens. Prior to the blast, Lebanon had a migration challenge where the World Bank data indicates that about 40 percent of male and 30 percent of female university graduates leave Lebanon upon graduation (WorldBank 2014). While it is still too early to tell what the migration impact of the explosion will be, the total population of Lebanon has dropped .44% last year and (Ibrahim 2020) reports that the number of people leaving Lebanon increased by about 30% in the first month after the blast. Understanding the decision making process of social entrepreneurs is critical since they are an important part of the population working on creating stability and creating positive reasons for people to stay, either through their services, as employees or customers.

So what is a theory behind humor and this buffering effect? Humor has been linked to adaptive coping and keeping a “light attitude” in the face of adversity (Ruch and Hofmann 2017). Humor is also an active response to take when other options are unavailable: people “break” the silence with laughter, for example. This may be preventing the processes which lead to Learned Helplessness. Learned helplessness is one way to view the opposite of post traumatic growth for people living in highly chaotic and destabilized situations. Initially Learned Helplessness theory implied that dogs experiencing inescapable shocks learned helplessness and persisted in helpless behavior even when the situation became escapable later. 

Recent research has shed light on the neurological underpinnings of learned helplessness which has application in uncertain times (Maier, S. F., & Seligman, M. E. P. 2016). Previously Learned Helplessness, as the name suggests, theorized that higher level mammals learn helpless behaviors when they are given inescapable negative experiences. Passivity in the face of a changed situation, a situation where it behooves the animal to take action, is the hallmark of learned helplessness. And while that behavior doesn’t change, our understanding of how it comes to be has. Mammals, when confronted with prolonged adverse situations, develop an unlearned response of passivity. The first sentence of the first paragraph should pick up some or most of the words from the title. You need to articulate the issue your paper addresses within the first three sentences to satisfy the expectations of your readers and maintain their attention. For the opening sentence of the introduction, be sure to avoid sweeping generalizations
The second paragraph of the introduction should provide a context and motivation for the current investigation. Typically, there are two reasons to write a paper: the study or ex- periment is the logical next step in a line of in- vestigation, or prior studies have been some- how deficient in some way that the current study addresses. You should decide which rationale best justifies your study. If it is the first reason, then the literature review should focus on the most important two to four articles (you can reference many more if you like), and show how this line of investigation has led to your study. If the reason is the inadequacy of previous studies, then the two to four most im- portant studies should be cited and their deficiencies explicitly stated. You will try to jus- tify your contentions by means of examples, proofs, or reasons, or by providing a narrative unfolding of the details or intricacies of the is- sue. As a rule, avoid referring to papers using author names (e.g., Anderson, Lee, and Wilson report in their 1967 study that...). Such strings of proper names tend to slow the pace of the writing and become altogether too cumbersome. Rather, state the point you want to make about the study and reference it with a number at the end of the sentence.
The third paragraph of the introduction should open with the explicit statement of the overarching reason your study is needed, drawing from the preceding paragraph. The last sentence of this paragraph should begin, “The purpose of this study was to...” Readers have a very strong and fixed expectation that the purpose of the study will be found in last sentence of the last paragraph of the introduc- tion. Do not worry about being unoriginal: this is not creative writing (at least in the common sense), but rather formulaic, patterned writing. A busy reviewer does not want to search for certain elements of the paper: these should be where he or she expects to find them, like tools in their rightful place.

Abstract
  
Background: The movement of Palestinians in the occupied Palestinian territories is restricted by bureaucratic and physical obstacles. To date, no studies have examined the barriers that Palestinian medical students face in accessing hospitals for clinical training. The objectives of this study were to characterize these barriers and understand how they affect Palestinian students’ medical education and quality of life.
Methods: Convenience sampling was used to recruit 4th-6th year medical students from Al-Quds University to participate in focus group discussions. A total of 36 students participated in the discussions. Transcripts of the discussions were coded to identify major themes.
Results: Palestinian medical students expressed facing numerous challenges during their clinical training. Students emphasized the difficulties of obtaining permits to train at Jerusalem hospitals, including arbitrary permit rejections and long wait times. Significant delays, searches, and mistreatment at checkpoints during their commute to hospitals were particularly burdensome. The majority of students who participated in the focus groups felt that their education and quality of life had been strongly negatively affected by their experience trying to access hospital training sites.
Conclusions: Our findings suggest that medical students living and studying in the occupied Palestinian territories receive sub-optimal training due to ambiguous permit rules, barriers at checkpoints, and the psychological burden of the process. These results highlight the impact that military occupation has on the education and quality of life of Palestinian medical students in a setting in which there is regular violence and many health indicators are already poor.

ABSTRACT
This study documents the perceptions and experiences of immigrant women and men in the US related to female genital cutting (FGC). This paper examines the effects of migration on these perceptions, with the goal of op- timizing health services and informing public policy to support women who have undergone FGC. This quali- tative study consisted of individual interviews conducted from 2014 to 2015 with 42 women and men living in Boston, Massachusetts, who immigrated from a variety of communities where FGC has been practiced. Most participants felt strongly against the continuation of the practice, describing a change in their personal and community viewpoints over time, which they attributed to education, religion and immigration. The men in our study collectively took a stand against FGC and believed that they had a particular duty to raise awareness in their families and their communities about its physical and emotional harms. Our study provides strong support for the inclusion of men, religious leaders, and immigrants in FGC-related efforts. Our unique preliminary ex- ploration of the role of members of the diaspora provides some support for initiatives that would involve emigrants in the effort to curb FGC in their home countries. Changing views in the diaspora could play a sig- nificant role in affecting opinions and practices in contexts where FGC is prevalent. Finally, our findings do not support the fear that “vacation cutting” might be common among US immigrants. We should therefore exercise caution in our promotion of legislation and clinical practices that target this fear.

1. Introduction
The World Health Organization defines “female genital mutilation” as a procedure involving removal of or injury to the female genital organs for non-medical reasons (WHO, 2008). More than 200 million women and girls have undergone female genital cutting (FGC) globally, with an additional 3 million girls under the age of 18 “at risk” each year (WHO, 2008). While the practice varies widely, much research has shown that women who undergo FGC face negative health and social consequences (Ball, 2008; Utz-Billing and Kentenich, 2008; WHO, 2008). FGC is classified into different types (WHO, 2014): Type 1 in- volves removing part or all of the clitoris or the prepuce. Type 2, in- volves removing part or all of the clitoris and labia minora, with or without the labia majora. Type 3, called infibulation or pharaonic, in- volves removing part or all of the external genitalia and narrowing the vaginal orifice by reapproximating the labia minora and/or labia ma- jora. Type 4 encompasses all other harmful procedures to the genitalia
for non-medical reasons. The term sunna, meaning “prophetic tradi- tion”, is generally used to describe non-infibulating forms of FGC.
1.1. The United States
In 1996, the United States Congress banned FGC. In 2000, Brigham and Women's Hospital's African Women's Health Center used census data to estimate that 228,000 girls living in the US had either under- gone or were at risk of FGC. This represented approximately a 35% increase from the 1990 census data (Nour et al., 2006). More recent estimates tell us that 513,000 girls under the age of 18 in the US are now at risk of FGC—more than three times the number in 1990 (Goldberg et al., 2016). Researchers attribute this increase in estimated number of girls at risk to increased migration from FGC-practicing countries as well as a change in the estimation technique to include both first and second generation girls (Goldberg et al., 2016).

1.2. The persistence of FGC
Various reasons have been cited for the persistence of FGC including its role as a rite of passage, the preservation of chastity, ensuring marriageability, religious requirements, hygiene, and enhancing sexual pleasure for men (Nour, 2008; WHO, 2008; Mackie and LeJeune, 2009). A systematic review of 21 studies of members of communities that practiced FGC but reside in Western countries pointed to six key factors underpinning FGC: cultural traditions, sexual morals, marriageability, religion, health benefits, and male sexual enjoyment (Berg and Dension., 2013). In almost all the studies included in that review, FGC was referred to as a meaningful and valued cultural practice linked to honor and the preservation of chastity, enforced through community mechanisms. The current study seeks to avoid oversimplifying the practice and immigrants’ perceptions of it by presenting complex and often contrasting views among a diverse set of immigrant women and men.
1.3. Community based research in immigrant populations
Some research has examined perceptions and experiences of FGC in African diasporic communities in the United States (Akinsulure-Smith, 2014; Connor et al., 2016; Johnson et al., 2009; McNeely and Jong, 2016). A qualitative study among 30 female Somali refugees in Min- nesota found that participants endorsed negative attitudes towards FGC, largely secondary to health consequences as well as a new un- derstanding that FGC is not sanctioned religiously (Connor et al., 2016). A qualitative study among 13 Somali refugees in Colorado found that all participants reported having changed their views on FGC after moving, often due to education, migration, and dissociation of the practice from religious beliefs (McNeely and Jong, 2016). Lastly, a study among Somali immigrant women about their challenging FGC- related healthcare experiences in the US emphasized the importance of engaging in community-based participatory research using mixed- methods to build trust-based networks and actively engage community members in the research process (Johnson et al., 2009).
There is also research on FGC among African diasporic communities outside the United States (Abdulcadir et al., 2016; Jaldesa and Abdi 2014; Vloeberghs et al. 2012). A study in Nairobi found that Ethiopian immigrants viewed FGC as a tool to curb female sexuality and enforce fixed gender roles upon women; those researchers called for commu- nity-based education programming involving religious leaders, NGOs, government ministries, and other actors (Jaldesa and Abdi 2014). A study of immigrants from Sub-Saharan Africa residing in Hamburg, Germany found that most immigrants speak out for the abandonment of FGC, but that there is a solid minority who maintain either positive or indifferent attitudes towards the practice (Behrendt, 2011). Other stu- dies also reflect this overwhelming rejection of FGC after immigration (Johnsdotter et al., 2007), while some studies delineate certain groups of immigrants that may tend to have more traditional views towards the practice, such as males, older generations, and new arrivals (Morison et al., 2004). There are differing views on the kind of effect the process of migration has on the viewpoints of immigrants on FGC. One fra- mework might suggest that immigrants may cling more strongly to cultural norms such as FGC in an effort to retain their cultural identity, while an opposing theory might suggest that immigrants are more likely to abandon a practice such as FGC in the process of assimilation (Berry, 1997).
1.4. Men's perspectives
Few studies in the US have explored the varied perspectives of men on FGC. A recent study in Somalia indicated that 96% of men preferred to marry women who have undergone FGC but that women were less likely than men to support FGC (Almroth et al., 2001). Similarly, a study in Oslo found that Somali immigrant men were more likely than

women to support continuation of the practice (Gele et al., 2015). However, a qualitative study in the US found that male Somali refugees were aware of FGC-related morbidities and did not support the practice, while many women seemed supportive (Johnson-Agbakwu et al., 2014). More detailed comparisons of men and women's views in the US are needed to determine how perceptions of FGC itself and FGC-tar- geted interventions might be similar or different across gender lines.
1.5. Objectives
This study documents the FGC-related perceptions and experiences of immigrant women and men in Boston, Massachusetts, and attempts to understand the effect of migration on these perceptions, with the larger goal of optimizing health services and informing public policy to support women who have undergone FGC. Our study is unique in considering not only the views of women who have undergone FGC (not simply all women from FGC-practicing countries), but also the views of immigrant men from the same communities. Furthermore, this study investigates the nature of FGC-related communication between mem- bers of the diaspora and relatives in their communities of origin across Africa and the Middle East—an important facet of the subject that past studies have not investigated.
2. Methods
We designed a qualitative study consisting of individual interviews in Boston, Massachusetts, with immigrant women who experienced FGC themselves and immigrant men with family members who had experienced FGC, to explore their views on the practice and the dis- course surrounding it. We report our qualitative research in accordance with the COREQ criteria (Tong et al., 2007).
2.1. Ethics, consent, and permissions
This study was approved by the Brigham and Women's Hospital Institutional Review Board (IRB). Informed consent was obtained verbally and participants were provided with a study information sheet. No compensation or incentives were given to study participants.
2.2. Topic guide
The topic guides for the interviews were created by the researchers based on gaps in the literature related to the perspectives and experi- ences of people in the US who immigrated from communities where FGC has been practiced. The topic guides, one tailored to men and the other to women [Appendix A] were reviewed for content, clarity, and cultural sensitivity by Harvard Medical School faculty of both African and Middle Eastern descent. The topic guides consisted of three sec- tions: participants’ personal views on FGC and the cultural and social factors that have affected their views; personal experiences with FGC and its long-term effects; and perceptions of community views of the practice both in their countries of origin and in the US diaspora.
2.3. Sampling
Convenience sampling was used to recruit both women and men living in Boston who had immigrated from communities where FGC has been practiced, including parts of Egypt, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Ghana, Mali, Nigeria, Somalia, Sudan, and the United Arab Emirates. Inclusion cri- teria included women and men above 18 years of age who immigrated from these countries and now live in Boston. For women, it was ne- cessary that they themselves had undergone FGC. For men, it was ne- cessary that they had a family member who had undergone FGC. Individuals who were below 18 years of age or women who had not undergone FGC were excluded.

After the interviews, participants were asked whether their part- ners, relatives, or friends in their communities would be willing to participate (snowball sampling). If so, a separate interview date was set up to consent and interview additional participants.
2.4. Interviews
Interviews were conducted in a semi-structured format between July 2014 and 2015 until thematic saturation was reached. Interviews ranged between 20 and 90 minutes in duration. All interviews were conducted either in Arabic, English, Somali, or Tigrinya. The interviews were conducted in the participants’ own languages (one interviewer was fluent in Arabic and another in Tigrinya), and a Somali interpreter was used when needed. 25 interviews were conducted in English and the remaining 17 were conducted in the other languages. The re- searchers took notes and audio-recorded during the interviews then subsequently translated and fully transcribed the interviews in English on an encrypted laptop. All interviews were translated into English to produce written transcripts.
2.5. Qualitative data analysis
We employed Joffe and Yardley's qualitative research guidelines for our thematic analysis (Joffe and Yardley, 2004). Two researchers open- coded the transcripts of the interviews using thematic analysis to identify major underlying themes. The two researchers initially read through a sample of interviews separately and independently drafted a list of recurrent codes derived from the data (inductive coding). All coding was done using MAXQDA 11. Codes were identified in- dependently then refined collaboratively to ensure good inter-coder reliability. The coders discussed discrepancies between their codes until they reached consensus, then finalized a list of reoccurring themes based on the frequency with which each code was identified throughout the interviews. The nuances of these high-frequency codes were then explored. Key themes and illustrative quotations were reviewed by the researchers for consensus.

3.2. Perceptions of FGC
3.2.1. Rationales for the practice
A primary aim of this study was to explore how immigrant women who have undergone FGC and immigrant men conceive of the practice. Participants cited a range of rationales for the creation and perpetua- tion of FGC. In response to the question “Why do you think the practice is performed?,” all 42 participants agreed with the response “preserve chastity,” 24 participants agreed with “culture,” 14 participants agreed with “religion,” 6 participants agreed with “ensure marriage,” 3 parti- cipants agreed with “rite of passage,” 2 participants agreed with “curb sexual desire,” one participant agreed with “enhance sexual pleasure for men,” and 1 participant agreed with “hygiene.” Virtually all parti- cipants considered FGC a primarily cultural rather than religious practice, and some argued that the two—religion and culture—are not distinct categories, as they readily intersect in daily life.
In contrast to meta-narratives of FGC as a means to “preserve chastity,” a 68-year-old Eritrean man and a 65-year-old Ethiopian man described how some Eritreans and Ethiopians decide to have their daughters undergo Type III FGC in order to protect them from being raped. A 64-year-old Nigerian man explained that, in his community of origin, people believed that FGC was necessary to reduce the chances of a woman experiencing stillbirth. Lastly, a 42-year-old Malian man de- scribed FGC as both a physical and spiritual ritual of initiation into womanhood.
3.2.2. Perceived effects of the practice
Many participants believed that there were no advantages to FGC,
often explaining that it does more harm than good. A 30-year-old Egyptian woman used strong, human rights-based language in her re- sponse:

For one 35-year-old Eritrean woman, for example, having under- gone FGC forms a barrier to social acceptance in Boston, particularly in healthcare settings, as she must face the stigma of FGC as ‘backward’ and ‘primitive.’ Thus, having experienced FGC can serve as both a means of gaining social acceptability and of being socially ostracized, depending on the local power dynamics.
3.3. Gendered dynamics of FGC: exploring the roles of men
In discussions with both women and men about the roles of men in the dynamics of FGC, two primary sub-themes emerged: notions of marriageability in relation to men's preferences and the potential for men to act as advocates against FGC in their families and communities.
3.3.1. Marriageability and men's preferences
Some participants argued that at the center of discourses on FGC, marriageability, and men's preferences lies the importance of virginity in the construction of the ‘good,’ ‘desirable’ woman. A 30-year-old Somali woman explained that, in the context of exploring marriage options, discussions around having undergone FGC often serve as a means of discussing virginity, an important quality to her in the larger sociopolitical context of marriage and desirability.
In contrast, other participants argued that men desired a woman who had not undergone FGC and therefore had supposedly stronger sexual desires. A 65-year-old Ethiopian man described men's pre- ferences and the stigma against circumcised women in certain parts of Ethiopia: “In some areas, men prefer uncircumcised women [...] Because they think that if she's circumcised, that she's ‘resa’, like a dead body without sexual feeling.” Similarly, one 40-year-old Sudanese man discussed the importance of enjoying sex with his wife, who had un- dergone FGC and was not re-infibulated after giving birth to her first child:
They [young men] say that the woman who isn't circumcised is more happy, more heated—she will have more enjoyment with him. So I don't know. [...] They say that when she is circumcised she will not be hot, not be sexy, but I don't feel that. In my experience, I've had a happy and fulfilling life with my wife and we have enjoyment. [...] Even when she had our first son, my friends would say, "Let her go back to Sudan and get re-circumcised", but I said, “No. Why?”
Thus, we found a range of men's preferences with respect to FGC and indications that some preferences had changed over time.
3.3.2. Men as advocates for change
The majority of participants, both women and men, highlighted the changing perspectives of men and their potential to serve as advocates
against FGC, especially through their dual roles as family and com- munity members. Both men and women discussed the intimate roles of men as supportive husbands. A 40-year-old Sudanese Muslim man de- scribes his first sexual experience with his wife after they were married:
When we went on our honeymoon, I told her I'm not gonna push her. She took one and a half months with me. [...] In the stories I had heard and the books I read, it [painful sex] can make the woman hate the man. I didn't want her to resent me so I said take it easy and slowly. It took us about 2 months and we were both satisfied.
Both male and female immigrants to Boston described how, as hus- bands, the men facilitated their wives' access to healthcare providers at the African Women's Health Center after having negative experiences with physicians with limited awareness of the practice of FGC.
A 32-year-old Somali man described his stance as the father of a young girl:
As a man, it's just a theory. I'm not sure what it [FGC] is. You will never know or understand things unless it happens to you and it's personal. I've heard it's an awful thing...Would I do it to my daughter? No. I have a daughter and it's not part of my agenda and it's not part of anything anyone can convince me to do.
Similarly, a 40-year-old Sudanese man spoke of the responsibility of fathers to stop the practice: “I think the role of men is important, especially for fathers. If you're the father and you know this is about to happen to your daughter, ask yourself: why is this happening? And if you don't believe in it, then stop it from happening.” A 32-year-old Eritrean man described his changing position and his role in persuading his mother to prevent his youngest sister from undergoing FGC. Thus, many male participants viewed their roles as fathers and siblings, among others, as critical in FGC-related decision-making regarding the women and girls in their families.
Furthermore, some participants argued that men, given their dominant position within the hegemonic social order, bear a particular responsibility to advocate against the practice—alongside their part- ners—at both the family and community levels. A 33-year-old Ethiopian man highlighted men's roles as advocates against FGC, ar- guing that their privileged status strongly implicates them in the practice:
The involvement of men in the fight against FGC is absolutely im- portant, because of their positions of power. If they are convinced, they can change [other people's] positions. So given the structural relations, I think their involvement is absolutely important. Because, for example, in a particular family if the husband says no, I don't think the practice will continue.
While these participants stressed the roles of men in changing discourse around and practices of FGC, others also highlighted the roles of women. A 30-year-old Somali woman, for instance, explained that de- spite her and her husband's opposition to the practice, two out of five of her daughters underwent FGC because of her mother-in-law's pre- ferences.
3.4. Religion
3.4.1. Muslims and Christians
Religion played an important role in our interviews with both Muslim and Christian participants. The central question for both Christians and Muslims was whether FGC was mandated, condoned, or forbidden by their respective religions. When asked about whether participants felt that FGC was a religious practice, some participants made reference to their primary texts, with some believing that FGC is specifically mentioned in the Bible or the Quran, and others believing that it was not. A 62-year-old Eritrean Christian man commented, “I think that both Christians and Muslims exercise that [FGC]. What I know is that most of them exercise it for cultural reasons.” Many

participants believed that FGC was unrelated to their religion and was instead a reflection of cultural tradition. One participant, a 65-year-old Eritrean man, remarked, “In religious practice in the Orthodox Church, the priests never spoke about it being done, but I also never heard them condemning it. To me, it comes more from the civilian culture in Eritrea and Ethiopia, especially on the Christian side.” A 35-year-old Eritrean man commented, “I've read a little bit about it in the Bible. The Bible doesn't say anything about a girl being circumcised, only about boys. In our society, especially among the older ones, they mix the culture and religion.” A 43-year-old Somali Muslim man similarly explained, “There is nothing in our religion, nothing that says we should circumcise. It is not in religion or anything.” However, despite controversy over its re- ligious legitimacy, there seemed to be agreement among participants that FGC is practiced by both religious groups, although some Christian participants believed it to be more strictly practiced by Muslims.
3.4.2. Sunna
In discussion with Muslim participants, the question of the practice's religious basis took on an additional dimension in the discourse around the different types of FGC, namely sunna versus the pharaonic type (Type 3). Although the term sunna can be used to describe non-in- fibulating forms of FGC, our population generally used it to refer to Type I FGC. A 26-year-old Somali woman explained, “There are two kinds of practice, one is sunna, set up by the holy Quran and the Prophet Muhammad, and the other is pharaonic, which is totally wrong. That's the one I'm against.” Around a fourth of participants (11/42, 26.2%) shared this view: that Type 3 was unacceptable due to its deleterious effects on women's health and sexuality, but that Type 1 might be ac- ceptable because it is a comparatively minor procedure without any perceived long-term effects. A few participants even mentioned that a common strategy used by some transnational campaigns and religious groups in their countries of origin to discourage severe forms of FGC was to encourage Type I over Type III FGC.
3.4.3. Religion as a means for change
Many participants referred to religious leadership as an important factor in swaying public and personal opinion against FGC. A 33-year- old Somali Muslim woman spoke about these dynamics in Somalia: “The situation has changed [...] a lot of sheikhs [Muslim religious scholars] came and spoke out and said how dangerous it is for the girls to be harmed. So they stopped. Very soon, they might even stop the sunna”. A 52-year-old Somali Muslim man said, “Some people still do the procedure, but it's not that popular. I hear that people spoke against the procedure. They said it's torture, if you do this to your daughter, you'll have to answer in the Hereafter, so it's not as popular as befor- e—the religious scholars speak out against it.” Many participants echoed the view that religious leaders play a critical role in influencing public opinions by denouncing the practice. In fact, many participants felt that it was much easier for them to abandon and discourage the practice themselves if they believed it was not religiously mandated. As a 40-year-old Somali Muslim woman recounted:
Where I grew up when I was young, they do it. [...] Our parents were not educated, they don't know what it is, they think this is a part of religion, it's like cultural things. But the good news is that after we flee the country, and got educated and found out more that it has nothing to do with our religion, it is very bad, it is not a sunna [Prophetic tradition], no hadith [Prophetic saying], or aya [Quranic verse], so now our people who left the country they don't do it, but those who still in the country they do it. That's why we try to educate each other. Like if you have a sister, and she has daughter we say don't do it, we have kids now, we don't do it. Like, for ex- ample, I have four children born in America so I don't do it because we follow the practice of our religion, and our religion did not say do it at all, so this thing is just cultural, it has nothing to do with our religion.
Many participants shared similar experiences in which the act of emi- gration itself allowed for a reframing of the relationship between re- ligion and perceptions of FGC, making it easier for them to abandon the practice. A few Muslim participants even noted that immigrating to the United States and meeting Muslims who had emigrated from commu- nities where FGC is not practiced further persuaded them that FGC was not a mandated Islamic practice.
3.5. Changes in perspectives on and practices of FGC
The final theme of our interviews was the potential for change in opinions on FGC, both in immigrants’ communities of origin as well as in the US. The overwhelming majority of participants we interviewed, both men and women, believed that both the prevalence of and popular support for FGC had decreased. Participants attributed this decline to both personal and community-level changes relating to (from most to least commonly attributed) education, urban-rural divides, crim- inalization of FGC, generational differences, emigration, transnational and national campaigns, religious leaders, and medical personnel.
3.5.1. Sources of change
These changes in opinions on FGC were overwhelmingly attributed to increased education, particularly regarding the harms and health risks of FGC. A 31-year-old Somali woman explained succinctly, “There is a faction that says it [FGC] is something necessary to our culture, and there are some people who see it as a backwards practice. The differ- ence between these people are their education levels.” Differences in education were also often linked to generational differences. One 42- year-old Sudanese woman noted, “This [FGC] used to be widespread during the time of our mothers and the generations past but now that people are aware and they know that the circumcision has a lot of complications and that it is not right, people have begun to distance themselves from it.” A 33-year-old Somali woman affirmed, “People now have a lot of education; people my age don't agree with the practice, but people in older generations still support it. But now young people know the risks.”
In addition to education, the criminalization of FGC in their coun- tries of origin was cited by participants as a significant factor in the perceived decline in the prevalence of FGC. However, many partici- pants noted that criminalization was not enough. A 55-year-old Eritrean man noted:
The government in Eritrea declared a proclamation so that by the law the practice gets punished. Whether people accept the law is a different question. To convince people, you have to do civil educa- tion and education through religious institutions and you have to do different efforts. Just because you have a law, it doesn't mean you will see many changes. [...] There is still much more work that needs to be done. Because with religion and culture, [...] it is dif- ficult and troublesome to change people's perspectives.
Thus, participants stressed the importance of education and advocacy in changing public opinion and the practice of FGC. A 25-year-old Ghanaian Christian man recalled, “For a while growing up, there was a lot of education against it [FGC]. So most communities have done away with it. But unfortunately in some communities it still persists. [...] The good thing was that most people got on board, presidents made public declarations, chief imams [Muslim religious leaders] were some of the biggest people who spoke up against it.”
Many participants had memories of various media outlets such as TV campaigns, documentaries, and news articles that helped them change their own views on the negative effects of FGC. A 28-year-old Somali woman said that she thought that the prevalence of FGC, especially of Type III, had decreased in Somalia, “because everybody is talking about the health problems like infection, bad periods, problems with peeing. They make community organizations, women tell the men and the moms and tell them to stop the pharaonic type. It's the doctors
