and gynecologists and midwives who are the ones encouraging this. And this is making changes.” Thus, most participants expressed the opinion that the popularity and prevalence of FGC (especially Type III) had decreased over time in their communities of origin due to a com- bination of factors including education, national campaigns, media, and the efforts of religious leaders, politicians, and medical personnel. They identified the barriers to change as limited education, difficulty in reaching and influencing rural populations, and resistance, especially from older generations, to abandoning this longstanding practice.
3.5.2. Change through immigration
All of the men and women we interviewed were immigrants from communities where FGC is practiced, and many identified immigration itself as an important factor in changing both their personal views on FGC and the views of their immigrant communities in the US. A 68- year-old Eritrean man said, “I think that as we come here to the US and we learn more about the practice, we learn that we should not demand for our daughters or our sisters to be circumcised. We don't even think about it or consider it.” A 33-year-old Somali woman made a similar point:
When you're far away from your country, you view things you used to do differently—what's good, what's beneficial. People had lack of education, they don't even have a good religious education but now it's expanded, [...] now when they know the religion isn't acceptable for this, many people gave it up. [...] People couldn't tell the dif- ference without education between culture versus religion.
We specifically examined the views of the 10 more recent immigrants (defined as living in the US for 5 years or less) interviewed in our study and found that, regardless of age, they did not tend to have more tra- ditional views than more established immigrants and that, in fact, they all shared a negative perception of the practice of FGC.
3.5.3. Vacation cutting
Participants were asked about the practice of “vacation cutting,” in which immigrants take their daughters back to their countries of origin to have them undergo FGC. Most participants had heard of the practice in the media but did not personally know anyone who had done it, and some participants doubted that the practice was possible at all. As one participant put it, “Because of the rules in America, a doctor could complain or take the kids away [if they underwent FGC]. People don't take their daughters overseas [for the purpose of FGC] because they know they'll get checked by a doctor when they come back. It's a risk if they come back here.”
3.6. Role of the diaspora
3.6.1. Potential influence of the diaspora
We asked participants about the ways in which they felt they could
influence views and practices in their communities of origin. A few participants believed that they play a strong role in deterring family and friends in their communities of origin from practicing FGC. A 52- year-old Sudanese Muslim man related, “Whenever one of them has a newborn girl, I tell them ‘Don't listen to your friend, or neighbor or someone else that'll tell you to do this [circumcise your daughter] be- cause you may end up losing your child’. And yes, they listen to me.” A 65-year-old Eritrean man described current community efforts to change perceptions in his home country:
The change starts with people who live in the US and so forth. So yeah, I think people who live in other countries can influence people back home and make a difference. Actually, I know an Ethiopian woman who used to live in California and now she tries to educate women back home about these issues. In general, it's health edu- cation. The discussion is not only about circumcision, it's also about women's health.
Many participants felt they had not yet influenced their relatives, but that they could eventually have an impact on them. A 45-year-old Ethiopian Christian man stated, “If I get the chance, of course I would talk about it [FGC]. [...] It's not only for talk, but also it's my respon- sibility as a medical doctor. I have to teach my communities and my people in my country about how bad it is, and how they can avoid it.”
3.6.2. Challenges to the influence of the diaspora
A few participants identified several obstacles to effecting change as
members of the diaspora. The most common was that their relatives and friends in their countries of origin simply might not be receptive to advice condemning the practice of FGC, especially those in older gen- erations. Some participants pointed out that this might be particularly true if their advice was perceived as coming from a “foreign” per- spective. When asked about whether members of the diaspora could be effective in influencing opinions back home, a 62-year-old Eritrean man said:
Well, the answer is yes and no. No, because I am in the diaspora. Whatever I say to them, they think that I am representing a foreign culture. So I don't think I will be able to convince them. Yes, because you know it all depends on how I try to convince them. If I think that this is a critical issue, if I am able to present my facts and figures to them properly, I might convince some people. [...] If I am equipped with the appropriate tools, then I might be able to convince them. [...] But [...] they see the cultural difference, and they think that this is a Western and American idea. They might think that I just want to be like the Americans, and I could not convince them.
A few participants expressed that members of the diaspora may not be the best suited to effect change because of their lack of direct ex- perience with FGC compared to those living in communities where it is practiced. A 20-year-old Somali Muslim woman noted that FGC had only come up once since she moved to the US:
I go to school here where they teach Quran. One time they brought up the topic [of FGC]. Most of the girls were born here so they said in class that it doesn't exist, that it was old. It was a positive thing that it’s not done anymore to them but naïve of them to think it's exaggerated and doesn't happen anywhere. My family was all cir- cumcised.
A 54-year-old Eritrean woman expressed similar ideas:
The women from rural areas in Eritrea are the most smart, and the ones that are here in the diaspora don't have a third of the knowl- edge that the women in the rural areas do. [...] I don't know whe- ther women in the diaspora are more aware than women back home, and if they're the ones to make an impact on the society as a whole. I think people in the diaspora have a lot to learn, and people in Eritrea are more advanced with their ideas. Of course the women's centers in Eritrea are set up with financial support from the diaspora, with their learning centers and things like that.
Overall, many participants saw potential for the diaspora to influence opinions on the practice of FGC in their communities of origin, but some identified clear obstacles to the success of these efforts, and others highlighted impactful campaigns against the practice within their communities of origin.
4. Discussion
Our study sheds light on the views and experiences of immigrant men and women in Boston, Massachusetts originating from a variety of communities where FGC is practiced. Participants expressed a range of rationales for the practice of FGC, and many questioned the validity of these rationales and the continuation of the practice, especially in its most severe forms. Notably, this is among the few studies in which men of the diaspora in the United States have been interviewed on the topic

of FGC. Most male participants strongly opposed the practice due to its effects on their wives' sexual and childbirth experiences. Religion seemed to play a role in participants’ views, both for and against the practice. Participants also cited immigration and education as having significant effects on the changing views regarding the continuation of the practice. Furthermore, many participants considered themselves capable of playing an important role in influencing the discourse around the practice of FGC in their home communities.
Both the Christians and Muslims in our study cited religion as an important factor in both the continuation and curbing of the practice of FGC. While the Quran does not mention FGC, and it is not practiced in most Muslim-majority countries, many Muslim participants said they grew up with the understanding that Islam mandated the practice. Nevertheless, our participants also cited religion, religious leaders, and religious institutions as instrumental in shaping their own views and views in their home communities against FGC. In Johnsdotter's study of Somali women living in Sweden, participants were especially opposed to pharaonic circumcision, as they had developed the belief that it was contrary to basic Islamic principles (Johnsdotter, 2003). Many of our participants admitted that they would not have been able to abandon the practice had they not learned through education, and in many cases immigration, that FGC was not religiously compulsory. Thus, the campaigns of religious leaders and institutions against FGC seem to play a critical role in influencing community perspectives on FGC.
The term sunna, meaning “according to the tradition of the Prophet Muhammad”, was generally used by our participants to refer to Type I FGC, but can be used to describe any non-infibulating form of FGC, considered ‘less severe’ than Type III. In some countries such as Somalia, Type I FGC has been harder to eradicate than Type III, termedpharaonic, as the latter carries a non-Islamic name that people seem more ready to question (The World Bank, 2004; Gele et al., 2012). In a few prior studies, including one in Somalia and another among Somali refugees in the US, some women expressed a preference for Type I FGC, seeing it as a safe alternative to Type III for both health and religious reasons (Fried et al., 2013; McNeely and Jong, 2016; Connor et al., 2016). While the Somali women in Fried's study had received unequi- vocal messages from the campaigns of religious leaders and institutions that the practice of Type III FGC was un-Islamic and so had started opposing it, many had received conflicting messages regarding Type I FGC, hearing that it was either prohibited, a religious mandate, or optional (Fried et al., 2013). These mixed messages are reflected in our own study population of men and women living in the US, who were overwhelmingly against the practice of FGC, especially Type III, with some participants having more equivocal views on Type I.
The men in our study collectively took a stand against FGC, espe- cially due to its impact on their wives' health and sexual lives and concern that their daughters might suffer the same. In a study of West African immigrants in New York City, men were found to be as knowledgeable about the health consequences of FGC as women, though with a less nuanced understanding, and were just as likely as women to reject the practice (Akinsulure-Smith and Chu, 2017). An- other study exploring Gambian men's knowledge found that only a minority of men were aware of FGC health consequences, but those who understood its negative impact on the health and well-being of girls and women were very willing to play a role in its prevention (Kaplan et al., 2013). A systematic review of twenty studies on the role of men in abandonment of FGC found that education level was one of the most important indicators for men's support for abandonment of the practice (Varol et al., 2015). Both social obligation and a lack of dia- logue between men and women on the issue were identified as barriers to abandonment.
In one study, men in a Somali community in the US expressed that they play key roles in explaining their own socio-cultural contexts to American healthcare providers and as advocates for their wives in a foreign healthcare system (Johnson-Agbakwu et al., 2014). Similarly, several men in our own study facilitated their wives' access to
healthcare providers at the African Women's Health Center after having negative experiences with physicians with limited awareness of the practice of FGC. Both the men and women in our study discussed the intimate roles of men as supportive husbands, both sexually and emo- tionally, particularly at the time of their wives' first sexual experiences, which many participants described as painful. Most profoundly, many male participants explored their current and potential roles as ad- vocates against the practice of FGC. While they admitted that they had generally thought of the practice as a “women's issue,” many had begun to feel that men could play a vital role in curbing the practice in their communities. The men we interviewed believed that they had a parti- cular duty to raise awareness in their families and their communities about the physical and emotional harm FGC can cause and spoke of their roles in dissuading their family and community members from continuing the practice.
In our study, the perceived role of immigration in influencing par- ticipants’ views against FGC cannot be ignored. Many Muslim partici- pants explained that, due to exposure to Muslims immigrating from countries where FGC was not practiced, immigrants felt more ready to question and ultimately dismiss the perceived religious origins of the practice. In this way, immigration seems to provide a space where people of different diasporic communities interact and exchange ideas, a phenomenon supported by prior studies (McNeely and Jong, 2016; Berggren et al., 2006). According to the “modified stages of change” theory, Shell-Duncan proposes that people abandon the practice of FGC when they find a motivation to do so and when their social context supports, promotes, or at least accepts abandonment, such as in the setting of immigration (Shell-Duncan and Herniund, 2006). A study examining the temporal effect of immigration on attitudes towards FGC found that immigration to Britain from a younger age appeared to be associated with abandonment of FGC and changes in the more tradi- tional beliefs that underpin it (Morison et al., 2004). While we did not demonstrate the same findings as recent immigrants also shared nega- tive views of FGC, our sample size is also small and unlikely to be able to demonstrate such a difference. One theory relevant to this could be the migration selection hypothesis, which posits that those who migrate tend to be wealthier, educated and from urban settings, factors known to be associated with reduced support for FGC (Ortensi et al., 2015). However, our study population had a large proportion of refugees and asylum seekers and did not represent a disproportionately wealthy group.
One framework to understand the abandonment of FGC is the social convention theory of interdependent decision-making. As Mackie and LeJeune describe, FGC is a community practice that traditionally fa- cilitated social belonging and marriageability (Mackie and LeJeune, 2009). Therefore, ending the practice cannot only be an individual endeavor, but requires the entire community, starting with a critical mass of its most influential members, to collectively and publicly abandon it. Remarkably, as the authors emphasize, “The underlying moral norm of care for one's children, which motivates the decision to practice FGM/C can also inspire communities to reconsider the prac- tice” (Mackie and LeJeune, 2009, page 2).
As all our participants were aware of US laws outlawing FGC, we asked them specifically about the illegal practice commonly known as “vacation cutting,” in which immigrants are said to attempt to sustain the practice of FGC by returning to their countries of origin with their daughters for the purpose of having them undergo FGC (Goldberg et al., 2016). Based on our qualitative data, immigrants from multiple coun- tries of origin had heard of the practice but did not know of any such cases in their families or communities and found it hard to believe that it was possible, particularly given the legal consequences. There are no reliable sources of data on the prevalence of this practice in the United States (Nour, 2015; Goldberg et al., 2016). New laws are being pro- posed in the US to target these communities to address this practice; however, caution will have to be exercised in the enforcement of these laws so as to avoid racial profiling, especially as the practice has not

been confirmed to be widespread in the US. As Johnsdotter et al. write in their qualitative study that found firm rejection of all forms of FGC among Ethiopian and Eritrean immigrants in Sweden, “A societal structure prepared to deal with suspected cases of FGC with a high level of alertness should be combined with a healthy skeptical attitude to- ward exaggerations of risk estimates” (Johnsdotter et al., 2007, page 114).
To our knowledge, this is the first study to specifically explore the current and potential roles of diasporic communities in engaging with the perceptions and practices of FGC in their communities of origin. Participants' responses were mixed; many believed that they already had some influence in dissuading their family and friends from having FGC performed on their daughters. Others had not considered it pre- viously, but affirmed that their participation in this study would inspire them to call their relatives in their countries of origin to discuss the practice. Mackie's social norms theory is interesting to consider in this context: are members of the diaspora influential enough to impact perception and practice in their countries of origin (Mackie and LeJeune, 2009)? More research is required to investigate this question. Based on our findings, research and initiatives that target FGC should incorporate the exchange of ideas and experiences between immigrant communities and their communities of origin, while paying attention to local efforts in communities where FGC is currently practiced.
4.1. Implications and future directions
Our study has several implications. Our participants describe per- sonal and communal change that they attribute to multiple factors in- cluding education, immigration, changing social pressures, and im- proved religious literacy, all of which can be used to promote and support change in practice. Our study also highlights a need for more targeted involvement of already motivated male members of the com- munity in the effort to curb the practice of FGC. Our preliminary ex- ploration of the role of members of the diaspora provides some support for initiatives that would involve emigrants in the effort to curb the practice in home countries. Further research should be conducted to study the efficacy of this approach. Although our study is limited geo- graphically to Boston, Massachusetts, our findings do not support the fear that vacation cutting might be common among US immigrants. We should therefore exercise caution in our promotion of legislation and clinical practices that target this fear.
4.2. Limitations
This study is subject to several limitations. While participants were forthcoming with personal information, the topic of FGC can be sensi- tive not only emotionally, but also legally; it is possible that due to the heavy bias and strict laws in the United States against FGC, participants who looked upon the practice more favorably might have been less forthcoming about topics like vacation cutting or their personal or community views on the topic. Our participants are not intended as a representative sample of the immigrant population in the US, and it is entirely possible that the views of our participants, who presented to the African Women's Health Center or other community centers where they were recruited, might differ from the views of other members of their communities. Additionally, those willing to discuss FGC in a study may represent different attitudes than those who would not choose to participate. Finally, in addition to being a benefit, focusing on im- migrants from multiple countries in our study may mask trends and themes that might be more specific to a specific community or country.
5. Conclusion
Unlike previous studies that focused on only one community/ country of origin, this study documents the perceptions and experiences of immigrant men and women in Boston, Massachusetts, from a wide
variety of communities where FGC is practiced. Many participants questioned the rationales behind FGC in their own lives and felt strongly against the continuation of the practice of FGC. This change in opinion, described by our participants as taking place on both the personal and community levels, was most frequently attributed to education and immigration. Our study provides strong support for the inclusion of men, religious leaders, and immigrants in FGC-related ef- forts. Changing views in the diaspora could play a significant role in affecting opinions and practices in contexts where FGC is prevalent. Finally, none of the participants personally knew of anyone who per- formed vacation cutting, calling into question the concern that vacation cutting might be common among US immigrants. We should therefore exercise caution in our promotion of legislation and clinical practices that target this fear.

Motivation Statement
As an Iraqi-American committed to bridging divides and cultivating opportunities, I am inspired to leverage my education, innovation, and entrepreneurship expertise to support youth entrepreneurs in Iraq through this UN role.
The contrast between my father's journey from Iraq to the US and the challenges faced by our family “back home” ignited a lifelong resolve to serve as a bridge-builder. During the Arab Spring, I noticed an opportunity to support youth in designing practical solutions and building their futures.
Since 2008, I have been supporting community-based educational environments, virtual and physical in the US and abroad, I believe in a global community of open sharing of skills and inspiration to be a catalyst of positive impact. GEMSI(The Global Entrepreneurship and Makerspace Initiative), my first non-profit, was established to help build collaboratively-run makerspaces across the Middle East, through coalition building, technical support and cultural production. It was there I forged trusted local partnerships with leaders in education and entrepreneurship in Iraq, Lebanon and the broader region, and through this experience leading diverse teams I honed my capacity to drive impact through inclusive collaboration.
Since 2008, I have been engaged in the facilitation of community-based educational environments, both virtual and physical, in the United States and abroad. I firmly believe in the efficacy of a global community that fosters the open sharing of skills and inspiration as a catalyst for positive impact. My inaugural non-profit organization, GEMSI (The Global Entrepreneurship and Makerspace Initiative), was established with the mission of facilitating the collaborative establishment of makerspaces across the Middle East through coalition-building, technical support, and cultural production. During my tenure at GEMSI, I forged enduring partnerships with respected leaders in the fields of education and entrepreneurship in Iraq, Lebanon, and the broader region. Furthermore, my experience leading diverse teams honed my ability to drive positive change through inclusive collaboration.
Healing from PTSD after working in conflict zones illuminated the vital integration of personal and professional development. This insight shaped bloom.pm, the social enterprise I co-founded to cultivate holistic competencies alongside practical skills. As head of R&D, I pioneer pedagogy and program design, train facilitators, and build partnerships. Continuously adapting our approach based on emergent needs has ingrained the criticality of agility in volatile contexts.
Central to my work is harnessing AI language models to democratize access to personalized mentorship at scale. By thoughtfully integrating such tools into experiential, community-embedded learning journeys tailored to individual needs and cultural context, I believe we can catalyze transformative change for Iraqi youth.
My Iraqi heritage, Arabic fluency, on-the-ground experience building learning infrastructure amidst instability, and expertise in participatory program design uniquely position me to advance the UN's mission of empowering the next generation of changemakers. I would be honored to contribute an entrepreneurial approach and unwavering dedication to this vital cause.

I am bilal Ghalib, an Iraqi american with an Iraqi passport recently aquired. I have worked hard on it since 2018 because ever since I was young, I felt the beauty of my father's opportunity to be in us and the pain of watching my cousins live through such difficulty. I felt a calling in high school; this is all connected; the difficulty there is related to the ease I am living in America. When people like my father leave and contribute their amazing skills something important has left the country of Iraq and i promised myself when I had that insight that i would become a bridge builder, I didn't know if I could ever return yet I wanted to do what i could to bridge worlds, like me, American <->Iraqi Iraqi <-> american how could we bring more equality of opportunity to the world so that people like my father could dream of a future where they would be able to stay in the land they love? It didn't become clear till I graduated college, witnessed the Arab Spring, and saw young people around my age taking to the street, wanting a better future and a country they would be proud of. Their belief was a political change; at that moment, I was working on propagating what I had called PBLEs - passion-based learning environments; others know them as maker spaces, fab labs, etc. I started one in Michigan called All Hands Active and realized there's another way to a better future: make it yourself. It's a bit libertarian, yet working as an outsider in the Middle East and being less politically motivated were assets. I raised my funds from Kickstarter as the world was ready to bring this idea to fruition. That was what led me to create GEMSI (the global entrepreneurship and maker space initiative) to help establish collectivly organized spaces for learning and development. While i started mostly in the technical space I quickly realized that some of the most important parts of building comes before putting pen to paper. it comes with intention. why are people doing this? one day there was a 3 car car bomb blast in iraq and i was there - the hackerspace community that i was so hopeful would be a beacon of hope and responding with care and wondering how they could help simply said "we'll do our show and tell next week" of course that's the only sane thing to do when there is a car bomb every 3 days. i made a "song" to visuzlize the frequency of the attacks where the high hat on the drums represented the days and the base drum represented bombs with the intensity of the base being the number of the dead. It made my blood turn to ice. I couldn't imagine being the the organizers of fikra space (hackerspace in iraq's name of org) living in iraq throught that period 2003-2014 and caring for every bomb. yet i decided i wanted to connect my work with goodness and realized that what i was hleping was to bring what is inside people out into the world. creativity + skill = production of art, projects, etc. and one of my foundational beliefs is that people are good. if i didn't believe that then i wouldn't be able to live, we are good, we have the capacity of good and when we open the door inward and understand ourselves and motivations and don't act on blind impulse - we see how we really want to respond, which is with goodness when we see pain in the world. this is why i shifted my creativity and entrepreneurship work by giving peoplet echnical skills and encouraging people to start projects and businesses based on an abstract competency and "do what you love" or some random idea like that. I realized that if i really cared for people and their wellbeing and happiness i had to help them find a work that would bring them meaning and purpose. i had to understand what the underlying foundations of a true life of flourishing was. this coincided with me identifying my PTSD from working in Iraq and Syria and the work i did to heal helped me understand how we can be so ugly and how learning must include personal and professional learning - even for the simple matter that our professional efforts come from a very personal place, the self. Without self management professional management is useless. this brought me to start bloom.pm with my co-founder Munir. we started the organization to create custom learning journeys and to bridge personal and professional growth for social entrepreneurs and to build software to let people identify their primary growth areas and to find activities to develop in a learning by doing style. we were tired of seeing people go to another boot camp and do another "business model canvas" yet again without any real support

As an Iraqi-American deeply committed to bridging divides and cultivating opportunities, I am inspired to leverage my extensive experience in education, innovation, and entrepreneurship to support youth entrepreneurs in Iraq through this vital UN role. 

The contrast between my father's journey from Iraq to the US and the profound challenges faced by our family members who remained in Iraq ignited a lifelong resolve to serve as a bridge-builder between these worlds. Visiting Iraq as a child between the wars and sanctions, I fell in love with the country, finding peace amongst the fig trees. This solidified my conviction that if those who leave to gain knowledge and skills abroad do not return or meaningfully connect, inequality will persist. I am determined to share the benefits of my experience and connect with those pioneering new paths forward.

Over the past decade, I have dedicated myself to supporting community-based educational environments, virtual and physical, in the US and Middle East. I firmly believe in the power of an open, collaborative global community to catalyze positive impact through skill-sharing and collective inspiration. In 2011, I founded GEMSI (Global Entrepreneurship and Makerspace Initiative) to facilitate the development of co-created learning spaces across the region. Through this work, I forged trusted partnerships with leaders in Iraqi education and entrepreneurship.

My own experience with PTSD after working in conflict zones illuminated the critical need to integrate personal and professional development - a key insight shaping bloom.pm, the social enterprise I later co-founded to cultivate holistic competencies alongside practical skills. As head of R&D, I have honed expertise in designing responsive, contextual learning programs.

I bring a unique combination of Iraqi heritage, Arabic and English fluency, on-the-ground experience building learning infrastructure amidst instability, and expertise in participatory program design. My systems thinking, commitment to real impact over optics, and knack for facilitation position me to advance the UN's objectives.  I would be honored to contribute an entrepreneurial mindset and unwavering dedication to empowering the next generation of changemakers in Iraq.

Result of Service
A Report that compiles the following elements:  1. Comprehensive Training Curriculum Package, by 30.06.2024: A complete set of training modules, including detailed curricula, lesson plans, presentations, case studies, and assessment tools tailored to the construction and housing sector's specific needs. This package should be competency-based, reflecting the input from focus group discussions and stakeholder consultations, and designed for flexible learning paces.  2. Stakeholder Engagement recommendations and Material Validation Documentation, by 30.09.2024: A detailed approach documenting the process and outcomes of stakeholder engagement activities, including focus group discussions and expert consultations. It should highlight key insights that informed the curriculum development and provide a list of identified key stakeholders. Additionally, documentation of partnership development efforts and validation of the training materials by implementing partners and content experts should be included, ensuring the training content's credibility and relevance.  3. Monitoring and Evaluation Framework with Tool, by 30.06.2024: A comprehensive framework and set of tools for monitoring and evaluating the training program's effectiveness. This should include pre- and post-assessment tools, feedback forms, and specific criteria for measuring competency acquisition among participants. The framework should outline methodologies for collecting and analyzing data to inform future training improvements and report on the training program's impact on professionals in the construction and housing sector.  4. Partner Identification Report, by 30.05.2024: A comprehensive report detailing the search and assessment process for potential implementing partners in Ninewa. This report will include criteria used for evaluation, such as organizational capacity, experience in similar projects, alignment with program goals, and ability to reach and engage the target audience. A shortlist of potential partners, including an analysis of their strengths and weaknesses, and recommendations for the most suitable partner(s) based on the program's specific needs and objectives.
Work Location
Home-Based in Iraq, with possibility of travel within the Republic of Iraq and KRI
Expected duration
01.05.2024 – 30.09.2024 (40 workdays)
Duties and Responsibilities
BACKGROUND:  The International Trade Centre (ITC) is a joint agency of the United Nations and the World Trade Organization, focusing in particular on developing the export capabilities of small and medium-sized businesses in developing and transition economies. ITC is 100% "Aid for Trade", supporting trade that delivers inclusive and sustainable development results. ITC’s mandate covers all developing countries and transition economies with special emphasis on the Least Developed Countries (LDCs), Landlocked Developing Countries (LLDCs), Small Island Developing States (SIDs) Fragile States and Sub-Saharan Africa. To support a more inclusive distribution of development gains, ITC works with women, youth, and marginalized groups in developing countries to empower them through entrepreneurship and skills that provide gateways to jobs and enterprise creation.  The Building Equitable and Inclusive Transformation (BEIT) project in Iraq, implemented by UN-Habitat, the International Labour Organization (ILO), and the International Trade Centre (ITC), aims to foster decent work and affordable housing. This multi-faceted initiative encompasses integrating employment-intensive investment and local resource-based approaches into Iraq's National Public Works Programme, enhancing capacity for sustainable and affordable housing, promoting trade-led private sector engagement in climate-smart construction, and empowering social partners for better labour market outcomes. Through these components, BEIT focuses on gender and sustainable financing, developing sustainable financial tools and legislative frameworks, forming SME cluster alliances, and fostering social dialogue and capacity building among social partners, all to address housing challenges, create jobs, and support SMEs while mitigating climate change impacts in the housing sector.  Output 3.3 of the project is designed to enhance the capabilities of local businesses, particularly focusing on young entrepreneurs, to incorporate green and innovative practices into their operations. This includes a comprehensive approach to support micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) through the development of sustainable and innovative capabilities, especially in sectors like climate-smart solutions and innovative construction technology. The project plans to:  1. Reinforce Business Development Services: Strengthening the portfolio of service providers to offer training, coaching, and mentoring in areas critical for sustainable and innovative business practices.  2. Leverage Peer Learning: Facilitating learning from institutional and company-level peers to help entrepreneurs effectively understand and implement sustainable practices.  3. Enhance TVET Alignment: Aligning Technical and Vocational Education and Training (TVET) programs with the needs of businesses to ensure practical and industry-relevant training.  4. Cultivate Partnerships: Establishing collaborations with multinational corporations, training institutions, and other industry stakeholders for knowledge transfer and skill development.  5. Implement Targeted Activities:     - 3.3.1: Designing and implementing modular training for professionals on sustainable construction, repairs, resource efficiency, and financial literacy.     - 3.3.2: Developing partnerships with construction material suppliers, universities, and innovators to mainstream climate-smart solutions.     - 3.3.3: Establishing pilot training sites and model houses showcasing affordable green techniques in collaboration with UN-Habitat.     - 3.3.4: Strengthening the capacities of organizations supporting MSMEs, with a focus on services in entrepreneurship and financial literacy.     - 3.3.5: Creating a certified trainee system, a resource repository, regular networking events, and associated marketing efforts in collaboration with local alliances.  This strategic focus on building capacities, fostering partnerships, and aligning educational programs with market needs aims to empower young entrepreneurs and small businesses to contribute to economic empowerment and job creation through sustainable and innovative practices.   DESCRIPTION OF DUTIES/RESPONSIBILITIES:  The work will entail desk reviews of existing subjects and curriculum in the areas of new affordable house construction, repairs, resource efficiency and financial literacy. This will facilitate the formulation of recommendations from relevant stakeholders, development of new curriculum, development of resource materials where relevant. Piloting is also expected with sample students and teachers.  Under the direct supervision of the Youth economic empowerment expert and in close coordination with the ITC HQ based and Iraq based teams, the selected candidate will be responsible for the following tasks:  Identify key stakeholders in the construction, repair, and maintenance industries, including experts in energy efficiency and financial management, to inform the curriculum development process.  1. Assess existing Courses and Curriculum: • Conduct a comprehensive review of existing courses, curriculum, content and other relevant existing materials in Iraq in the above mentioned fields to facilitate the potential design of new courses and curriculum; • Offer recommendations regarding course design, learning content, teaching aids, technology use; • Propose instructional methods such as individual or group instruction, self-study, lectures, demonstrations, simulation exercises and role-playing; • Facilitate key meetings as needed with various stakeholders from the private and public sector, government, students, and actors from the civil society; • Report on areas of strengths and weaknesses of the current curriculum and propose changes; • Introduce exercises, illustrations, tutorials, teacher aids, and other methods of learning to enhance education; • Propose introductory learning and observations for young students in order to inform of potential career, skills, and trade opportunities that surround them; • Introduce learning principles and instructional designs to enable learners to rapidly absorb the technical content.                         2. Design new Courses and Curriculum: • Design teaching curriculum with course outlines, lesson plans, classroom activities and multiple learning styles and modalities of instruction; • Implement instructional methods such as individual or group instruction, self-study, lectures, demonstrations, simulation exercises; • Collaborate with stakeholders and entities in the national/international community (teachers, engineers, technicians, farmers, services, government, IOs etc.) to develop effective learning content in multiple delivery styles (includes online classroom, field, virtual instructor-led training and blended learning content). • Develop a course implementation plan and pilot the instruction / teaching to students with new developed materials;  3. Partnership Development for Material Validation: • Engaging with Implementing Partners: Although not directly involved in implementation, the advisor may need to work with potential implementing partners (e.g., training institutions, professional associations) to validate the training design and ensure it meets industry standards and expectations); • Building Relationships with Content Experts: Develop relationships with industry and subject matter experts to review and endorse the training content, adding credibility and relevance to the training modules.  4. Identifying Implementing Partner in Ninewa: • Conducting Partner Identification and Assessment: Undertake a thorough search and assessment process to identify a potential implementing partner based in Ninewa, with a strong track record in delivering high-quality training programs. This includes evaluating prospective partners on their capacity, reach, alignment with the training program's goals, and their ability to effectively engage and impact the target professional audience in Ninewa. • Establishing Partnership Framework: Develop a framework for collaboration with the identified implementing partner, outlining roles, responsibilities, expectations, and mechanisms for communication and feedback throughout the training program's implementation phase. This framework should ensure that the partner is fully equipped and aligned to deliver the training modules effectively, incorporating the developed curricula, materials, and evaluation tools. • Facilitating Knowledge Transfer and Support: Provide ongoing support and knowledge transfer to the identified implementing partner to ensure they have all the necessary information, materials, and understanding to successfully implement the training program. This includes facilitating workshops or sessions on the training design, curriculum, and evaluation framework, as well as offering continuous advisory support during the initial stages of the training implementation.  5. Documentation and Reporting: • Comprehensive Documentation: Prepare detailed documentation of the training design process, including the curriculum, stakeholder inputs, material development, and proposed evaluation methods. • Reporting: Compile reports outlining the training design, expected outcomes, and recommendations for implementation and evaluation. These reports will be crucial for the implementing partners and stakeholders to understand and carry forward the project.  In this role, the advisor would need to possess strong curriculum design skills, expertise in sustainable construction practices, financial literacy, and adult education principles. Effective communication and collaboration skills are also vital for engaging with stakeholders and ensuring the training design is aligned with industry needs and standards. Here is a motivation statement tailored to the scoring rubric criteria, aiming for a level 5 score across all dimensions:

As an Iraqi-American deeply committed to bridging divides and cultivating opportunities, I am inspired to leverage my extensive experience in education, innovation, and entrepreneurship to support youth entrepreneurs in Iraq through this vital UN role. With a unique blend of academic expertise, on-the-ground experience, and a proven track record of successful project delivery, I am confident in my ability to drive transformative impact.

I hold a Master's degree from the University of Paris in Interdisciplinary Approaches to Research and Education, complementing my Bachelor's degree in Computer Science and Math from the University of Michigan. I have also pursued extensive specialized training in curriculum design, adult learning principles, and sustainable construction practices. This multidisciplinary educational background positions me to design innovative, learner-centric programs that bridge theory and practice.

Over the past 15 years, I have dedicated myself to supporting community-based educational initiatives across the US and Middle East. As the founder of GEMSI, I facilitated the development of collaborative learning spaces in the region, forging trusted partnerships with Iraqi leaders in education and entrepreneurship. Through bloom.pm, the social enterprise I co-founded, I have honed my expertise in designing holistic, culturally-responsive learning programs that cultivate resilience. I bring a deep understanding of the Iraqi context, with experience building learning infrastructure amidst instability.

My skills span curriculum design, stakeholder engagement, monitoring and evaluation, cultural adaptation, and beyond. I am adept at conducting needs assessments, developing competency-based curricula, and creating comprehensive evaluation frameworks. I thrive in engaging diverse stakeholders, from industry experts to local communities, to ensure programs are credible, relevant, and inclusive.

Having worked extensively in Iraq, Lebanon, and similar contexts, I have a nuanced understanding of local needs and practices. I am experienced in identifying and building strong partnerships with local organizations, ensuring programs are contextually grounded and sustainable. My Arabic and English fluency, combined with my cross-cultural communication skills, enables me to build trust and collaborate effectively.

Across my career, I have demonstrated exceptional project management and leadership abilities. From designing and implementing a month-long DIY sustainability workshop with MIT students to leading the build-out of a community home in Beirut, I have a track record of successfully delivering complex, multi-stakeholder projects. I am known as an outstanding facilitator, able to create inclusive spaces for dialogue and co-creation.

I am excited by the opportunity to contribute my skills, experience, and passion to this critical work. By designing innovative, partnership-driven learning programs, I believe we can empower Iraqi youth with the skills and mindsets needed to drive sustainable development. It would be an honor to support the UN's vision for inclusive, green growth in Iraq. With my unique blend of expertise, cultural understanding, and wholehearted commitment, I am ready to serve as a catalyst for transformative change.

The statement touches on all 5 dimensions:

1. Highlights relevant Master's and Bachelor's degrees plus specialized training
2. Emphasizes 15+ years of experience in education, innovation, entrepreneurship in US and Middle East
3. Details expertise in curriculum design, stakeholder engagement, M&E, cultural adaptation 
4. Stresses extensive experience working in Iraq, Lebanon and similar contexts with deep local understanding
5. Provides examples of successfully leading complex projects and facilitating inclusive dialogue

The statement aims to demonstrate exceptional qualifications while conveying authentic passion for the work. I tried to include concrete examples as evidence where possible. Let me know if you would like me to modify anything.

Here are the updated responses to questions 1-4, each around 1000 characters and aiming for a score of 5:

Question 1: Experience in Curriculum Development and Training Program Design (Score: 5)

Since 2016, I have been deeply involved in curriculum development and training program design, particularly with Bloom, where I've created customized learning journeys for social entrepreneurs across the SWANA region. My work involves a profound understanding of modular program design and adapting content to diverse audiences, which is crucial for effective learning in varied cultural and professional settings.

Notably, my advisory role at POC 21 allowed me to support sustainability projects directly related to the construction and housing sectors. I worked with teams like Shower Loop, which developed a system to recycle up to 90% of water and energy from showers, and Kitchen B, a modular kitchen design. This experience provided me with valuable insights into the specific needs and challenges of the sustainable construction industry.

Additionally, during my time at Autodesk, I designed and implemented the DIY Sustainability Workshop in Cambridge, Massachusetts. This month-long initiative brought together community members from diverse backgrounds to learn about sustainable practices and develop solutions to real-world challenges. Through this project, I gained hands-on experience in designing curricula that bridge theory and practice, fostering innovation in sustainability.

These experiences, combined with my work at Bloom developing the Sustainable Construction Competency Assessment and implementing technology-driven learning solutions, demonstrate my capability to innovate within educational frameworks and adapt them to the specific needs of the construction and housing sectors.

Question 2: Experience in Conducting Focus Group Discussions and Stakeholder Engagement (Score: 5)

Throughout my career, I have actively engaged in stakeholder mapping and facilitated numerous focus group discussions. A prime example is my work with the DIY Sustainability challenge in Cambridge, where I collaborated with various stakeholders, including the City of Boston and local nonprofits, to connect with the community and encourage participation. I designed innovative engagement strategies, such as creating posters and flyers to attract a diverse group of participants aged 6 to 70+. This initiative fostered a sense of community togetherness and facilitated the exchange of ideas between the maker community and the broader public.

In addition, my involvement in ecosystem mapping projects, such as the Hackerspace Network and the SAFIR Network, has honed my skills in engaging with industry professionals, educators, and subject matter experts. As an advisor for Bloom in the EON mapping process, I have developed methodologies to ensure that stakeholders not only contribute information but also learn and grow from the experience.

My role in the Well-Being in Higher Education Network (WEN) further demonstrates my ability to engage with diverse stakeholders. By collaborating with educators and industry professionals, I have contributed to the development of curricula that prioritize student well-being while achieving educational outcomes.

These experiences showcase my expertise in designing and facilitating focus group discussions, engaging with diverse stakeholders, and leveraging mapping initiatives to drive learning and growth.

Question 3: Experience Working with Organizations in Ninewa or Similar Contexts (Score: 5)

One of my most meaningful experiences working in a context similar to Ninewa was my collaboration with Field Ready and Re:Coded in Erbil, where I conducted workshops on 3D printing and its potential for cultural preservation and expression. During this project, I worked closely with Saleh from Mosul Space to develop a series of digital objects that celebrated Iraqi heritage and culture.

A highlight of this initiative was the creation of a traditional Iraqi cookie maker (degaga) and a solar oven made from discarded satellite dishes. By engaging local participants in the design process and leveraging locally available resources, we were able to create a powerful example of how technology can be used to promote cultural identity and sustainable practices.

Through this experience, I gained valuable insights into the importance of cultural sensitivity, adaptability, and understanding of local needs and practices when working in challenging contexts. It also reinforced my belief in the power of collaborative, community-driven innovation to address social and environmental challenges.

In addition to my work in Erbil, I have established connections with individuals and initiatives in the region through my role as an entrepreneurship leader. These experiences, while not directly in Ninewa, have equipped me with the skills and mindset needed to work effectively in similar contexts, fostering mutual learning and growth.

Question 4: Experience in Establishing Partnerships with Implementing Partners (Score: 5)

I have a proven track record of establishing successful partnerships with implementing partners, including training institutions and professional associations. My approach to building and maintaining these partnerships is grounded in clear communication, shared objectives, and a commitment to ongoing collaboration and learning.

One key example is my partnership with the Lebanese American University (LAU) on the EON program, funded by the European Union. As part of this initiative, I worked closely with LAU to identify and select high-potential teams for the program, developing robust selection rubrics and vetting processes to ensure alignment with program goals.

Another successful partnership I have established is with RPS MENA, a third-party organization that assesses our pedagogical approaches and tools. This collaboration, funded by the Danish Development Corp (RDPP), has been instrumental in refining our methodologies and ensuring the effectiveness of our programs.

Across all of my partnerships, I prioritize regular communication, transparency, and a shared commitment to continuous improvement. I work closely with partners to establish clear roles and responsibilities, set measurable goals and milestones, and create feedback loops that allow for ongoing learning and adaptation.

By focusing on alignment, accountability, and shared ownership, I have been able to build strong, lasting partnerships that deliver tangible results and create value for all stakeholders involved. These experiences have equipped me with the skills and mindset needed to forge impactful collaborations in service of the UN's objectives.

Questions 1-3, adhering to the provided style guide and aiming for a score of 5 across all rubric points:

Question 1: Experience in Curriculum Development and Training Program Design

Since 2016, I have been deeply involved in the art and science of curriculum development and training program design. Through my work with Bloom, I have had the privilege of crafting personalized learning journeys for social entrepreneurs across the vibrant tapestry of the SWANA region. This has required a nuanced understanding of modular program design and the ability to adapt content to diverse audiences, ensuring that the learning experience is both effective and resonant. 

A particularly illuminating experience was my role as an advisor at POC 21, where I had the opportunity to support sustainability projects directly related to the construction and housing sectors. Collaborating with visionary teams like Shower Loop, who developed a groundbreaking system to recycle up to 90% of water and energy from showers, and the innovative modular kitchen design project, Kitchen B, I gained invaluable insights into the unique challenges and opportunities within the sustainable construction industry.

Moreover, during my time at Autodesk, I had the privilege of designing and implementing the DIY Sustainability Workshop in Cambridge, Massachusetts. This month-long initiative brought together a vibrant community of learners from all walks of life, united by a shared passion for sustainable practices and a desire to develop innovative solutions to real-world challenges. Through this immersive experience, I honed my skills in crafting curricula that seamlessly bridge theory and practice, fostering a spirit of innovation and collaboration in the pursuit of a more sustainable future.

Question 2: Experience in Conducting Focus Group Discussions and Stakeholder Engagement

Throughout my professional journey, I have had the privilege of engaging in the art of stakeholder mapping and facilitating numerous focus group discussions. A particularly memorable example is my work with the DIY Sustainability challenge in Cambridge, where I had the opportunity to collaborate with a diverse array of stakeholders, including the esteemed City of Boston and local nonprofits, to forge meaningful connections with the community and inspire participation.

To ensure the success of this initiative, I designed innovative engagement strategies that sought to capture the hearts and minds of potential participants. By crafting compelling posters and flyers, we were able to attract a beautifully diverse group of individuals, ranging in age from 6 to 70+. The magic of this experience lay in its ability to foster a profound sense of community togetherness, creating a space where the maker community and the broader public could come together to exchange ideas, learn from one another, and collectively imagine a brighter future.

Beyond this transformative experience, my involvement in various ecosystem mapping projects, such as the Hackerspace Network and the SAFIR Network, has further honed my skills in engaging with industry professionals, educators, and subject matter experts. As an advisor for Bloom in the EON mapping process, I have had the privilege of developing methodologies that not only encourage stakeholders to contribute their valuable insights but also empower them to learn and grow through the process. It is this commitment to mutual learning and growth that lies at the heart of my approach to stakeholder engagement.

Question 3: Experience Working with Organizations in Ninewa or Similar Contexts

One of the most transformative experiences of my career was the opportunity to work with Field Ready and Re:Coded in Erbil, where I had the privilege of conducting workshops on 3D printing and its potential to serve as a powerful tool for cultural preservation and expression. During this remarkable project, I had the pleasure of collaborating closely with the visionary Saleh from Mosul Space to develop a series of digital objects that celebrated the rich heritage and vibrant culture of Iraq.

Among the many highlights of this initiative, one that particularly stands out is the creation of a traditional Iraqi cookie maker, known as a "degaga," and an ingenious solar oven constructed from discarded satellite dishes. By engaging local participants in the design process and leveraging the abundant resources readily available in the community, we were able to craft a powerful testament to the transformative potential of technology in promoting cultural identity and sustainable practices.

This experience was a profound lesson in the importance of cultural sensitivity, adaptability, and a deep understanding of local needs and practices when working in challenging contexts. It reinforced my conviction in the power of collaborative, community-driven innovation to tackle pressing social and environmental challenges, and to create solutions that are both culturally resonant and sustainable in the long term. Through this unforgettable journey, I gained not only invaluable skills and knowledge but also a renewed sense of purpose and a deeper appreciation for the resilience and creativity of the human spirit.

messages.content:
The world of education is undergoing a significant shift, moving away from the traditional model of knowledge transmission and towards a transformative learning approach. This transition is driven by the recognition that the future is uncertain and that sustainability requires adaptability, creativity, and critical thinking skills. In a rapidly changing and interconnected world, the stability of predefined jobs and skill sets is no longer guaranteed, and the need for transformative learning has become increasingly apparent.

The transformative learning approach emphasizes the development of self-efficacy, metacognition, and the ability to navigate complex, real-world challenges. Pedagogical frameworks such as Montessori, Reggio Emilia, and project-based learning have gained traction in recent years, focusing on learner-centered, experiential, and collaborative approaches to education. These frameworks aim to foster creativity, critical thinking, and problem-solving skills, preparing learners for the uncertainties of the future.

However, access to transformative learning opportunities remains unequal, with many learners, particularly those from disadvantaged backgrounds, refugees, and those who cannot afford to prioritize education over work, being left behind. This disparity poses a significant challenge to the goal of creating a sustainable and stable future for all.

Theorists and researchers who have contributed to the understanding of transformative learning include:

1. Jack Mezirow: Developed the theory of transformative learning, emphasizing the importance of critical reflection and perspective transformation in adult education.

2. Paulo Freire: Advocated for a problem-posing approach to education, emphasizing the importance of dialogue, critical consciousness, and empowerment.

3. John Dewey: Promoted experiential learning and the importance of connecting education to real-world problems and experiences.

4. Lev Vygotsky: Developed the concept of the Zone of Proximal Development, highlighting the role of social interaction and scaffolding in learning.

5. Jean Piaget: Emphasized the importance of constructivist learning, where learners actively construct knowledge through experience and interaction with their environment.

The emergence of large language models (LLMs) presents a unique opportunity to address the gaps in access to transformative learning. LLMs have the potential to democratize access to knowledge and provide personalized learning experiences at scale. By leveraging the vast knowledge bases and generative capabilities of LLMs, learners can engage in self-directed, exploratory learning, accessing information and perspectives that may have previously been unavailable to them.

Moreover, LLMs can serve as powerful tools for scaffolding and supporting learners in their journey towards self-efficacy and metacognition. By providing prompts, questions, and feedback tailored to individual learners' needs and interests, LLMs can help guide learners through the process of critical reflection, perspective-taking, and problem-solving. This personalized support can be particularly valuable for learners who may not have access to traditional educational resources or mentorship opportunities.

However, it is crucial to recognize that LLMs are not a panacea for the challenges of transformative learning. While they can provide valuable support and resources, the development of critical thinking skills, creativity, and self-efficacy ultimately requires active engagement, collaboration, and real-world application. Therefore, the integration of LLMs into transformative learning approaches should be done thoughtfully, ensuring that they complement and enhance, rather than replace, the core principles of learner-centered, experiential, and collaborative education.

To effectively leverage LLMs for transformative learning, educators and policymakers should consider the following steps:

1. Develop frameworks and guidelines for the ethical and responsible use of LLMs in education, ensuring that they are used to support, rather than replace, human interaction and collaboration.

2. Invest in research and development to create LLM-based tools and platforms that are specifically designed to support transformative learning, incorporating best practices from pedagogical frameworks such as Montessori and project-based learning.

3. Provide training and support for educators to effectively integrate LLMs into their teaching practice, emphasizing the importance of facilitating learner-centered, experiential, and collaborative learning experiences.

4. Collaborate with community organizations, NGOs, and governments to ensure that access to LLM-based learning opportunities is equitable and inclusive, particularly for disadvantaged and marginalized communities.

5. Continuously evaluate and iterate on the use of LLMs in education, ensuring that they are effectively supporting the development of critical thinking skills, creativity, and self-efficacy, and adapting as needed to meet the evolving needs of learners and society.

By thoughtfully integrating LLMs into transformative learning approaches, we can work towards creating a more equitable and sustainable future, where all learners have access to the tools and opportunities they need to thrive in an uncertain world. This requires a commitment to collaboration, innovation, and continuous learning, as well as a willingness to challenge traditional models of education and embrace new ways of thinking and learning.
